questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician for recurrent episodes of shortness of breath, nonproductive cough, and chest tightness for 3 months. These episodes occur especially while playing sports and resolve spontaneously with rest. She appears healthy. Her pulse is 63/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 102/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. Spirometry shows a FEV1:FVC ratio of 85% and an FEV1 of 85% of predicted. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the chest could reveal a pulmonary disease underlying this patient's respiratory symptoms. However, in this patient with symptoms suggestive of exercise-induced asthma, CT would be unlikely to reveal an underlying condition. In addition, the substantial amount of radiation should especially be avoided in this teenage girl.

B) CORRECT:

Exercise-induced asthma presents with symptoms of bronchoconstriction (e.g., shortness of breath, chest tightness) that typically peaks 10–15 minutes after beginning exercise. Exercise-induced asthma is treated with short-acting β2-agonists (e.g., albuterol) taken shortly (5–20 minutes) before exercise. Due to the risk of tachyphylaxis, β2-agonists should preferentially only be used before the most strenuous exercise sessions. Additional treatment options include avoiding exercise in cold weather (or using a mask to warm inhaled air) and avoiding triggers (allergic or environmental).

C) INCORRECT:

Prednisone therapy would not be the first-line therapy in exercise-induced asthma in a patient who has not tried other methods. Prednisone would generally be indicated if the patient had severe underlying asthma with an acute exacerbation that is not relieved by inhaled bronchodilators.

D) INCORRECT:

Although improved physical conditioning can improve minute ventilation and help improve the symptoms of exercise-induced asthma, this patient should initially be offered alternative management to help with her underlying disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography can be useful in young patients who present with symptoms suggestive of congestive heart failure (peripheral edema, crackles), hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (systolic murmur), or other valvular abnormalities. Cardiac involvement is unlikely in this patient whose physical examination showed no abnormalities and who has no symptoms at rest.
questions.hint: This adolescent girl has features of bronchoconstriction such as shortness of breath, nonproductive cough, and chest tightness only while playing sports. Her spirometry findings are normal. These findings suggest exercise-induced asthma.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician in December for episodic shortness of breath and a nonproductive cough for 3 months. These episodes frequently occur before sleeping, and he occasionally wakes up because of difficulty breathing. His mother also reports that he became short of breath while playing with his friends at daycare on several occasions. He is allergic to peanuts. He is at the 55th percentile for height and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows mild scattered wheezing in the thorax. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with cystic fibrosis (CF) may present later in childhood with respiratory symptoms such as dyspnea, coughing, and wheezing. However, the respiratory symptoms of CF are not episodic and the cough is often productive (due to pneumonia, bronchiectasis). Also, CF patients have a history of gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., meconium ileus, steatorrhea, failure to thrive), sinusitis, and pancreatic disease (pancreatitis, pancreatic insufficiency) during infancy, none of which is apparent in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with foreign body aspiration (FBA) usually present acutely with choking or coughing, dyspnea, and severe respiratory distress. Patients may also present days to weeks after the aspiration if the aspirated foreign body was small, got lodged in the lower airways, or if the initial choking went unnoticed. Such patients may present with recurrent cough and dyspnea, as seen in this child. However, pulmonary examination usually demonstrates wheezing or crepitus localized to the affected lobe rather than the scattered wheezing seen here. Also, the episodic presentation and nocturnal and exertion-induced exacerbation of symptoms in this child are suggestive of an alternative diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

A history of episodic dyspnea and cough that worsens at night and with exercise is highly suggestive of asthma. A normal chest x-ray, normal vital parameters when asymptomatic, and an auscultatory wheeze further support the clinical diagnosis of asthma. A history of other allergies (e.g., peanut allergy) raises suspicion of an atopic predisposition, making allergic, i.e. extrinsic asthma, which typically develops before 7 years of age, the most likely diagnosis.

Spirometry is the initial test of choice in patients ≥ 6 years of age. Findings of an obstructive lung pattern (↓ FEV1, ↓ FEV1/FVC ratio) that reverses with bronchodilation would confirm a diagnosis of asthma. Spirometry may be attempted in children < 6 years of age, but results are often unreliable. Therefore, diagnosis is largely dependent on a detailed history and the response to a trial of asthma medication. If the diagnosis is still nonconclusive, a methacholine challenge test may be attempted or watchful waiting initiated. Support x-ray is not always indicated and, if done, can be normal in mild cases of asthma or may show evidence of hyperinflation (e.g., flattened diaphragm, wide intercostal spaces). See “Differential diagnosis of chronic or recurrent wheezing in children” table.

D) INCORRECT:

Although children with cardiac failure can present with respiratory symptoms such as exertional dyspnea and wheezing (due to pulmonary venous congestion), they would also have additional cardiac findings on examination (e.g., tachycardia, tachypnea, rales on pulmonary auscultation, an S3 or S4 gallop, and/or features of the underlying cardiac pathology). Also, in patients with heart failure, the chest x-ray often shows cardiomegaly or increased pulmonary vascular markings.

E) INCORRECT:

While bronchiolitis can cause shortness of breath and is common during winter months, it usually affects children during early infancy (3–4 months of age) and is uncommon after 2 years of age. Also, it is not episodic, but manifests acutely, usually preceded by symptoms of an upper respiratory infection (e.g., low-grade fever/rhinorrhea), and patients often have signs of respiratory distress (e.g., tachypnea, intercostal retractions) at presentation. This 4-year-old child has episodic dyspnea and no evidence of acute respiratory infection.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) usually present during infancy with productive cough (due to recurrent respiratory tract infections and/or bronchiectasis) and recurrent sinusitis. The poor ciliary function also causes chronic otitis media and conductive hearing loss in many patients with PCD. This child has episodic dyspnea, dry cough, and no other clinical features of PCD, suggesting a different diagnosis.

G) INCORRECT:

Congenital tracheomalacia is a potential cause of stridor and brassy cough and usually occurs in children < 2 years of age, after which most cases spontaneously resolve. Although the symptoms of tracheomalacia may be episodic, this 4-year-old child was asymptomatic until recently, has scattered wheeze on examination, and does not present with stridor.
questions.hint: If this child could participate in spirometry, it would show reversible airflow obstruction.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for coughing, nasal congestion, and intermittent wheezing for the past 2 months. The child has a history of eczema. Since birth, he has had three upper respiratory tract infections that resolved without treatment, and one episode of acute otitis media treated with antibiotics. His family moved into affordable housing 3 months ago. His temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. There are scattered wheezes on pulmonary examination. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Flow cytometry showing absent or low B cell levels can diagnose Bruton agammaglobulinemia. Although this patient has had one episode of likely bacterial acute otitis media, patients with Bruton agammaglobulinemia tend to have recurrent and severe pyogenic infections, which is not consistent with this boy's history.
Image Description:

BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

B) CORRECT:

This patient likely has new-onset asthma, given his history of atopy (i.e., eczema) and chronic cough and wheezing after moving to a new home with possible allergen exposures (e.g., dust mites, cat dander). His prolonged nasal congestion suggests allergic rhinitis, which would complete the atopic triad. Spirometry is the initial test of choice in patients with suspected asthma ≥ 6 years of age. The presence of an obstructive lung pattern (↓ FEV1, ↓ FEV1/FVC ratio) that reverses with bronchodilation confirms a diagnosis. Spirometry may be attempted in children < 6 years of age, but results are often unreliable. Therefore, diagnosis is largely dependent on a detailed history and the response to a trial of asthma medication. If the diagnosis is still nonconclusive, a methacholine challenge test may be attempted.

C) INCORRECT:

Skin prick testing can be performed to identify allergens that may exacerbate this patient's cough and wheezing. However, he should first undergo a test that confirms his diagnosis. Skin prick testing can be performed for this patient in the future.

D) INCORRECT:

Throat culture would be appropriate for a suspected bacterial upper respiratory tract infection (e.g., Group A streptococcus). Although this patient presents with cough, nasal congestion, and wheezing, his symptoms have been present for 2 months, making an infectious etiology less likely. Instead, his symptoms can be better explained by a condition aggravated by repeat allergen exposure.

E) INCORRECT:

Serum IgA levels < 7 mg/dL with normal IgM and IgG levels are diagnostic of selective IgA deficiency. Most patients with selective IgA deficiency are asymptomatic, but some can have recurrent sinusitis or respiratory infections. Although this patient has had several upper respiratory tract infections since birth, the frequency is within normal limits.

F) INCORRECT:

Dihydrorhodamine 123 test can diagnose chronic granulomatous disease. Although this patient has had several infections, the frequency is within normal limits. Also, there is no evidence of infections with catalase-positive organisms.
questions.hint: This boy with eczema likely has a reversible condition triggered by allergens in his new home.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother for worsening wheezing and shortness of breath over the past day. He has not had a fever, cough, vomiting, or diarrhea. He has asthma and eczema. He uses a glucocorticoid inhaler and an albuterol inhaler but has missed his medications for the past week while on vacation. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 100/80 mm Hg. Expiratory and inspiratory wheezing is heard throughout both lung fields. There are moderate intercostal and subcostal retractions and a decreased inspiratory to expiratory ratio. Nebulized albuterol and ipratropium treatments and intravenous methylprednisolone are given in the emergency department for a presumed asthma exacerbation. One hour later, the child is limp and lethargic. Magnesium sulfate is administered. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 150/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. No wheezing is heard on repeat pulmonary examination. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Add leukotriene-receptor antagonists to nebulizer treatment
Add racemic epinephrine to nebulizer treatment
Perform needle thoracostomy at the 2nd intercostal space

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Leukotriene-receptor antagonists, such as montelukast, have not been shown to improve respiratory outcomes in pediatric patients presenting to the emergency department with acute asthma exacerbations.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has likely become hypercapnic from poor ventilation, resulting in altered mental status (lethargy) and inability to protect his airway. He requires intubation with mechanical ventilation to prevent respiratory arrest and/or hypoxic insult. Intubation should not be delayed for additional pharmacologic therapies.
Image Description:

BP: blood pressure
HR: heart rate
ICS: inhaled corticosteroid
ICU: intensive care unit
IV: intravenous
O2: oxygen
PEF: peak expiratory flow
PO: per os
RR: respiratory rate
SABA: short-acting beta agonist
SAMA: short-acting muscarinic antagonist
SpO2: oxygen saturation

C) INCORRECT:

Epinephrine is indicated for anaphylaxis, which can manifest with dyspnea, tachypnea, and wheezing. However, this patient does not have other typical features of anaphylaxis (e.g., sudden-onset flushing, urticaria, hypotension). Racemic epinephrine is also used in the management of croup, but this patient does not have consistent symptoms (e.g., barking cough, rhinorrhea, cough, fever). Epinephrine is not part of the standard treatment for severe asthma exacerbation.

D) INCORRECT:

Needle thoracostomy at the 2nd intercostal space is used for the treatment of tension pneumothorax. Although this patient has decreased breath sounds, they are decreased bilaterally with wheezing, making bronchoconstriction (secondary to status asthmaticus) a more likely cause of respiratory failure than a pneumothorax.

E) INCORRECT:

Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation can avoid the need for endotracheal intubation by providing respiratory support while waiting for pharmacotherapies to take full effect. However, intact mental status is required for the use of noninvasive positive pressure ventilation, as patients must be able to protect their airways to reduce the risk of aspiration. This patient's declining mental status (lethargic and limp) precludes the use of noninvasive positive pressure ventilation.

F) INCORRECT:

Bronchoscopy can be both diagnostic and therapeutic for children with foreign body aspiration, which can present as respiratory distress, as seen here. However, foreign body aspiration usually presents with the sudden onset of stridor in young children (< 3 years of age). Because this 6-year-old patient has a history of asthma along with worsening bilateral wheezing over the course of a day, status asthmaticus is a more likely cause of his respiratory distress.

G) INCORRECT:

There is little evidence to suggest that levalbuterol is superior to racemic albuterol in acute asthma exacerbations. Also, levalbuterol is significantly more expensive. More importantly, this patient has worsening respiratory failure despite albuterol nebulizers and therefore requires a higher level of treatment.

H) INCORRECT:

Although not part of most standard asthma protocols, heliox can be administered along with beta-agonists in patients with severe asthma exacerbations to improve laminar flow. However, this patient has impending respiratory arrest and requires a different step in management.

I) INCORRECT:

This patient will require at least 3 days of systemic glucocorticoids to reduce airway inflammation from his asthma exacerbation. However, methylprednisolone will take 2–4 hours for maximal effect. This patient has impending respiratory arrest that requires immediate management.
questions.hint: This patient has status asthmaticus, a type of severe asthma exacerbation. Despite initial treatment, he has a decline in mental status, decreased wheezing (due to poor aeration), and decreased respiratory rate (due to fatigue from increased work of breathing), which together are concerning for impending respiratory arrest.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man comes to the physician because of recurrent episodes of shortness of breath and a nonproductive cough for the past 4 months. He has two episodes per week, which resolve spontaneously with rest. Twice a month, he wakes up at night with shortness of breath. His pulse is 73/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 122/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Spirometry shows an FVC of 95%, an FEV1:FVC ratio of 0.85, and an FEV1 of 81% of predicted. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Short-acting beta-2 agonists (e.g., albuterol) are the treatment of choice for acute asthma symptoms and should be used as needed in patients with intermittent asthma. Patients who have intermittent attacks, in which the trigger of asthmatic symptoms is known and can be predicted (e.g., exercise-induced bronchoconstriction), can also use a short-acting inhaled β2 agonist as a prophylactic measure approx. 10 minutes before the triggering event (e.g., exercise). According to the National Asthma Education and Prevention Program (NAEPP), the low frequency of symptom occurrence associated with intermittent asthma only requires symptomatic treatment for acute exacerbations, whereas more severe forms of asthma require a constant therapeutic regimen to prevent exacerbations (see “Stepwise pharmacological treatment of chronic asthma” table).

The Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA), however, differs in its recommendations for intermittent asthma and recommends inhaled budesonide/formoterol as needed.

B) INCORRECT:

Fluticasone, an inhaled corticosteroid (ICS), can be used as an asthma controller. This medication gradually reduces the frequency of symptoms as well as the severity of each subsequent exacerbation. ICS-only treatment is not effective for relieving acute asthma symptoms because of its late onset of action, and ICS is typically given in combination with a beta-2 adrenergic agonist. Relief inhalers rather than control inhalers are indicated for patients with intermittent asthma.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral montelukast, a leukotriene-receptor antagonist, can be used as an asthma controller for the prevention of acute exacerbations of persistent asthma when a noncorticosteroid therapeutic alternative is desired. However, this class of drug is ineffective as an asthma reliever, and it would not be considered in this patient with intermittent asthma before other preferred controller medications.

D) INCORRECT:

Cromolyn sodium, a mast cell stabilizer, was previously used in bronchial asthma as a non-corticosteroid therapeutic alternative for long-term control of persistent asthma. It has no significant efficacy in controlling acute exacerbations.

E) INCORRECT:

Inhaled corticosteroids (e.g., mometasone) and leukotriene-receptor antagonists (e.g., zafirlukast) are used as asthma controllers. Relief inhalers rather than asthma controllers are indicated for patients with intermittent asthma. Additionally, leukotriene-receptor antagonists are mainly used in children and/or for specific subtypes of the condition (e.g., exercise-induced asthma, aspirin-induced asthma).

F) INCORRECT:

Salmeterol, a long-acting β2 agonist (LABA), can be used in combination with an inhaled corticosteroid for the prevention of acute exacerbations (i.e., asthma controller) in patients with moderate to persistent asthma. However, LABA-only treatment is not recommended in any class of asthma severity.
questions.hint: Shortness of breath and nonproductive cough ≤ 2 times per week and ≤ 2 nights per month with an FEV1  > 80% indicates intermittent asthma, which requires treatment to prevent asthma attacks and to relieve acute symptoms.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of dry cough and some chest tightness for the past 2 months. The cough is worse at night and while playing volleyball. She frequently has a runny nose and nasal congestion. Her mother has systemic lupus erythematosus. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 5 years. She does not drink alcohol. Her only medication is cetirizine. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Spirometry is the first-line diagnostic test for patients with suspected asthma. The presence of an obstructive lung pattern (↓ FEV1 and ↓ FEV1/FVC ratio) that reverses with bronchodilation confirms the diagnosis. Spirometry findings can remain inconclusive in patients with asthma who are tested during asymptomatic intervals. If initial spirometry cannot establish the diagnosis, repeat spirometry (during a symptomatic episode) or a bronchoprovocation test (i.e., methacholine challenge test) should be considered.
Image Description:

Patients with an obstructive lung disease typically have a concave flow-volume loop (middle) compared to healthy patients (left).
Emphysema typically causes a “scooped out” curve (right) due to the collapse of small airways during expiration.

B) INCORRECT:

Although the tentative diagnosis of asthma needs to be confirmed in this patient, mild asthma would not show any significant chest changes visible on an x-ray. A chest x-ray is only indicated in patients with severe persistent asthma to exclude the differential diagnoses.

C) INCORRECT:

The methacholine challenge test is a diagnostic test used to confirm asthma. However, it is a second-line test, and is employed only if the first-line test does not establish the diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the chest is rarely indicated in a case of suspected asthma. Considering the mildness of this patient's symptoms, no significant chest changes are expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Laboratory studies like antibody testing, CBC, and inflammatory markers are indicated in cases of asthma that are thought to be associated with infection or allergy. Although this patient has features that indicate atopy (suggested by a history of allergic rhinitis), these tests would only be carried out after confirming the diagnosis of asthma.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a chronic dry cough that worsens at night and with exercise. These features together with chronic allergic rhinitis (rhinorrhea, nasal congestion) suggest the diagnosis of asthma.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of episodic cough and shortness of breath. The cough is nonproductive and worsens when she climbs stairs and during the night. She has not had chest pain or palpitations. Eight weeks ago, she had an episode of fever, sore throat, and nasal congestion. She has a 10-year history of hypertension. She has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 16 years. Her only medication is enalapril. Her pulse is 78/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 145/95 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Diffuse end-expiratory wheezes are heard on pulmonary auscultation. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. Spirometry shows a FEV1:FVC ratio of 65% and an FEV1 of 60%. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pneumonia should be ruled out in patients presenting with dyspnea and cough with a recent history of an upper respiratory tract infection. However, the previous infection occurred 8 weeks ago and the protracted onset of the patient's current symptoms make an infectious etiology very unlikely. Furthermore, this patient has no signs of infection (e.g., fever, leukocytosis) and the chest x-ray shows no pulmonary infiltrates.

B) INCORRECT:

Gastroesophageal reflux disease can cause chronic, nonproductive cough and nocturnal cough due to laryngeal irritation and aspiration of gastric content in the supine position, which can then lead to pneumonia, asthma, or chronic bronchitis. However, the chief complaint is retrosternal burning pain (heartburn) that worsens while lying down (e.g., at night) and after eating, as well as dysphagia and regurgitation, which this patient does not have.

C) INCORRECT:

Congestive heart failure can cause exertional dyspnea and nonproductive cough, as seen in this patient. This patient's nightly dyspnea could indicate paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, and, along with her long history of arterial hypertension and smoking, should raise the suspicion of left-sided heart failure. The absence of other features, such as pulmonary edema, nocturia, or palpitations, however, makes this unlikely. Furthermore, the patient does not exhibit any signs or symptoms of right-sided heart failure (e.g., pitting edema, hepatomegaly).

D) INCORRECT:

Alpha-1-antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency is characterized by early-onset emphysema (including nonsmokers) and cirrhosis. Although spirometry would show an obstructive lung pattern (↓ FEV1, ↓ FEV1/FVC ratio), x-ray would show basilar emphysema. Liver disease due to intrahepatic accumulation of AAT would also be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

A relatively common side effect of ACE inhibitors, which this patient is taking, is dry cough due to an increase in bradykinin concentration. This typically occurs within 1–2 weeks after the initiation of treatment. Although a cough could potentially develop after years of treatment, it would be very unlikely. Regardless, episodic dyspnea, end-expiratory wheezing, and an obstructive lung pattern (↓ FEV1, ↓ FEV1/FVC ratio) would not be expected.

Other drugs, including beta-blockers, aspirin, and other NSAIDS, can trigger obstructive pulmonary symptoms (dyspnea, cough, wheezing). Patients with NSAID intolerance can develop aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD). Patients present with shortness of breath due to bronchoconstriction, malaise, weakness, fatigue, and/or skin flushing/rash after ingestion of aspirin or other NSAIDs.

F) CORRECT:

This patient with a 1-month history of episodic dyspnea, coughing, and wheezing that worsens during exertion and at night likely has new-onset asthma. Spirometry showing an obstructive lung pattern (↓ FEV1, ↓ FEV1/FVC ratio) supports this diagnosis. Unlike COPD, asthma is characterized by obstruction that is reversible with the administration of bronchodilators. A post bronchodilator test showing an increase of FEV1 of ≥ 12% (or 200 mL) confirms the diagnosis of asthma.

Although asthma most commonly manifests in childhood, it can manifest at any age, and nonallergic asthma in particular tends to occur in patients > 40 years of age. Nonallergic asthma can be triggered by viral respiratory infections and is exacerbated by exercise.

G) INCORRECT:

Chronic bronchitis is an important differential diagnosis in this patient, particularly considering her history of smoking, which is the main risk factor for chronic bronchitis. Patients usually present with (exertional) dyspnea, cough, end-expiratory wheezes, and an obstructive lung pattern on spirometry, which is the case here. However, the cough is usually chronic and progressive rather than episodic. Expectoration that typically occurs in the morning would also be expected. Furthermore, for the diagnosis to be made, pulmonary symptoms must be present for at least 3 months each year for 2 consecutive years, which is not consistent with this patient's history.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is most commonly diagnosed in children and adolescents but may also manifest in older adults.

questions.text: Thirty minutes after surgical nasal polyp removal for refractory rhinitis, a 40-year-old man has retrosternal chest tightness and shortness of breath in the post-anesthesia care unit. The surgical course was uncomplicated, and the patient was successfully extubated before arrival to the unit. He received 0.5 L of lactated Ringer solution intraoperatively. The patient was given morphine and ketorolac for postoperative pain. A similar episode happened 6 months ago when the patient took aspirin for a headache; symptoms resolved spontaneously within 3 hours. He has a history of obstructive sleep apnea, asthma, and hypertension. His daily medications include metoprolol and lisinopril. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen by face mask shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Wheezing is heard in both lungs. Breath sounds are decreased. The patient's face appears flushed. Watery nasal secretions and conjunctival injection are present. ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The use of non-selective beta-blockers can result in bronchospasm due to the inhibition of β2 receptors on the bronchial wall. However, metoprolol is a beta-blocker that selectively inhibits β1 receptors. It is therefore not the most likely cause of bronchospasm in this patient.

All beta-blockers can trigger bronchospasms in patients with asthma and β1-receptor selectivity is diminished in higher doses. Therefore, beta-blockers should be avoided in patients with severe or decompensated asthma. However, therapeutic doses of cardioselective beta-blockers (e.g., metoprolol) are generally well tolerated in patients with mild to moderate asthma.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperinflation of the lungs in a patient with emphysema can result in iatrogenic alveolar rupture; a 20-pack-year smoking history and the recent mechanical ventilation (intubated patient!) are therefore risk factors for alveolar rupture. Alveolar rupture would result in a pneumothorax, which presents with dyspnea and decreased breath sounds on the side of the pneumothorax. This patient developed wheezing and decreased breath sounds bilaterally after an infusion of ketorolac, making alveolar rupture unlikely.

C) CORRECT:

Samter triad is a feature of aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD). Patients with AERD develop symptoms resembling those of a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction (e.g., wheezing, decreased breath sounds, facial flushing) following the administration of aspirin or NSAIDs (e.g., ketorolac). Watery rhinorrhea and conjunctival injection are also commonly seen in AERD. Unlike a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction, which is an IgE-mediated process, AERD is a pseudoallergic reaction caused by the inhibition of cyclooxygenase (COX). Inhibition of the COX pathway increases the conversion of arachidonic acid to leukotrienes via the lipoxygenases pathway. Leukotrienes cause flushing and bronchial inflammation.

D) INCORRECT:

A type 1 hypersensitivity reaction causes bronchospasm and facial flushing. However, watery rhinorrhea and conjunctival injection are not expected. These features combined with chronic rhinosinusitis, nasal polyposis, NSAID hypersensitivity, and asthma make another cause more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

ACE inhibitors such as lisinopril can cause accumulation of bradykinin by inhibiting the enzyme bradykinin dehydrogenase. Increased levels of bradykinin typically result in a dry cough or angioedema, neither of which is seen in this patient. Bradykinin does have some bronchoconstrictor effect, especially if the patient has an underlying airway hyperreactivity (bronchial asthma). However, Samter triad and the onset of symptoms following the administration of ketorolac indicate a different mechanism for bronchospasm.
questions.hint: Chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyposis, NSAID hypersensitivity, and asthma together constitute Samter triad.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has a 3-month history of a nonproductive cough. He has been treated with diphenhydramine since his last visit 2 weeks ago, but his symptoms have persisted. He does not smoke. He drinks 3 beers on the weekends. He is 177 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 76 kg (168 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Physical examination and an x-ray of the chest show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin therapy in a patient with a history of cough can be indicated to treat suspected pneumonia. While a dry, nonproductive cough can occur in cases of atypical pneumonia, this diagnosis is unlikely considering the patient's age, absence of extrapulmonary symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, myalgias), and normal chest x-ray.

B) CORRECT:

Patients with chronic cough often receive empiric treatment for the most common underlying conditions, including upper airway cough syndrome (UACS), gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), and asthma. This patient's cough has persisted despite treatment with an antihistamine (diphenhydramine), making UACS unlikely. Since he has no symptoms suggestive of GERD (e.g., retrosternal burning pain, regurgitation), cough-variant asthma is the most likely diagnosis. Pulmonary function testing (PFT) is the first-line diagnostic step in patients with suspected obstructive lung disease. Spirometry showing an obstructive lung pattern (↓ FEV1, ↓ FEV1/FVC ratio) that reverses with bronchodilation (postbronchodilator test) confirms the diagnosis of asthma. If PFT does not yield a definitive diagnosis, a bronchoprovocation test can be performed.

C) INCORRECT:

Omeprazole therapy in a patient with a persistent cough is indicated if gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is suspected. While the connection is not fully understood, chronic cough in individuals with GERD is thought to be caused by a protective reflex following aspiration of gastric acid into the respiratory tract. Since GERD is unlikely to present only with a cough and no other typical features (e.g., retrosternal burning pain, regurgitation), this diagnosis is unlikely and another cause should first be considered.

D) INCORRECT:

A tuberculin skin test is used to screen at-risk individuals for asymptomatic latent tuberculosis. Risk factors for contracting tuberculosis include immunosuppression (e.g., HIV), malnutrition, living in prisons or homeless shelters, and being either native to or having traveled in an endemic area (e.g., India). This patient has no risk factors for contracting a tuberculosis infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral corticosteroids are reserved for managing severe, treatment-refractory asthma. This patient has no symptoms of severe asthma (e.g., severe dyspnea, hypoxemia) and a diagnosis has not yet been established.

F) INCORRECT:

CT scan of the chest in a patient with a history of cough are indicated to detect malignancies, lung consolidations (e.g., in tuberculosis), bronchiectasis, and pneumonia. Since this patient has no signs of infection or symptoms suggestive of malignancy (e.g., hemoptysis) and his chest x-ray shows no abnormalities, a CT scan is not indicated.
questions.hint: A chronic cough that has not resolved with a trial of an antihistamine requires further evaluation to rule out airway diseases.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of progressive shortness of breath and chest tightness for 3 hours. She has had an intermittent nonproductive cough for the past two months. Her 16-year old son had an upper respiratory infection last week and was treated with azithromycin. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years but stopped smoking 5 years ago. She works at a cattle ranch. She appears anxious and is unable to speak in full sentences. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5 F), pulse is 100/min, her blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg, and respirations are 28/min. A chest x-ray is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following sets of findings?



Chest excursion
Breath sounds
Chest percussion
Tactile fremitus



A
asymmetric
decreased
dull
decreased


B
asymmetric
absent
hyperresonant
decreased


C
symmetric
basal crackles
dull
increased


D
asymmetric
basal crackles
dull
increased


E
symmetric
decreased
hyperresonant
decreased
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

These findings are consistent with pleural effusion. When fluid infiltrates the pleural space it insulates sounds originating from the lung parenchyma, which results in a decrease in both breath sounds and tactile fremitus. Cough and dyspnea may be seen in pleural effusion, but there is no evidence of an effusion on this patient's chest x-ray.

B) INCORRECT:

These findings are consistent with pneumothorax. In this condition, the air in the pleural space leads to hyperresonant percussion and decreased tactile fremitus on the affected side. Pneumothorax should always be considered in patients with new-onset shortness of breath. However, there is no evidence of pneumothorax on this patient's chest x-ray.

C) INCORRECT:

These findings are consistent with pulmonary fibrosis. Patients with pulmonary fibrosis often have basal crackles on auscultation and can present with normal or increased tactile fremitus. Pulmonary fibrosis can manifest with dyspnea and a nonproductive cough, and it may be caused by farmer's lung, which this patient's occupation is a risk factor for. However, pulmonary fibrosis typically has a more chronic and progressive course than what is seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

These clinical exam findings are consistent with a consolidative process, such as lobar pneumonia. While pneumonia can also present with dyspnea, this patient lacks other symptoms of pneumonia, such as productive cough, fever, malaise, and/or chills. Furthermore, her chest x-ray does not have evidence of consolidation.

E) CORRECT:

Decreased breath sounds, hyperresonant percussion, and decreased tactile fremitus are consistent with pulmonary hyperinflation, which in this case is secondary to the patient's severe asthma exacerbation. Wheezing is another typical finding in asthma exacerbation but can be absent in very severe cases.

Based on her history, this patient likely has nonallergic asthma, which often manifests later in life and is associated with smoking exposure.
questions.hint: Chest x-ray shows parenchymal lucency, a low, flattened diaphragm, and wide intercostal spaces, all of which are signs of pulmonary hyperinflation. These findings, combined with the patient's history and clinical findings, are concerning for a severe asthma exacerbation.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of shortness of breath and dry cough for 2 days. His symptoms began after he helped his father clean the basement. He is allergic to shellfish. Respirations are 26/min. Physical examination shows diffuse end-expiratory wheezing and decreased inspiratory-to-expiratory ratio. This patient's symptoms are most likely being caused by inflammation of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Asthma typically has no effect on the pleural cavity. Inflammation in the pleural cavity can be due to an empyema, which typically presents with fever, pleuritic chest pain, and dyspnea, which is inconsistent with the patient's presentation.

B) INCORRECT:

Because alveoli are so thin-walled and lack smooth muscle, they do not contribute significantly to the bronchospasm that causes most of the symptoms in asthma. Inflammation at the alveolus is common in hypersensitivity pneumonitis, which usually results from exposure to birds or moldy plant matter. Though this patient has a recent mold exposure, his presentation is not typical of hypersensitivity pneumonitis, which usually presents with flu-like symptoms, dyspnea without wheezing, and rales on auscultation.

C) INCORRECT:

While inflammation of the respiratory bronchioles can occur in asthma, it does not contribute significantly to the onset of symptoms. Respiratory bronchioles don't have concentric smooth muscle, as there are gaps in their walls where alveoli branch out. Because of this, respiratory bronchioles are not the most likely location of bronchoconstriction and airway obstruction.

D) INCORRECT:

The distal trachea has cartilaginous rings to keep the airway patent, and as a result, does not contribute significantly to the bronchospasm that causes most of the symptoms of asthma. Inflammation of the trachea is common in croup, a disease that typically presents with a barking cough following a URI-like prodrome.

E) CORRECT:

The symptoms of asthma are primarily caused by inflammation of the terminal bronchioles. Terminal bronchioles are lined with smooth muscle but lack the cartilage found in larger airways. When an allergen triggers a hypersensitivity reaction there is bronchial submucosal edema and smooth muscle contraction and the airways collapse, as they don't have the support of cartilage. This collapse leads to the symptoms of asthma.
questions.hint: In a patient with a history of atopy, wheezing and prolonged expiratory phase after exposure to allergens (mold spores) are most likely signs of asthma.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with asthma is brought to the physician because of a 1-month history of worsening shortness of breath and cough. The mother reports that the shortness of breath usually occurs when he is exercising with his older brother. His only medication is an albuterol inhaler that is taken as needed. The physician considers adding zafirlukast to his drug regimen. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Binding of IgE is the mechanism of action of the anti-IgE monoclonal antibody omalizumab. Omalizumab is used in the treatment of severe allergic asthma involving high levels of IgE. This patient has mild to moderate exercise-induced asthma, so omalizumab would be inappropriate. Zafirlukast does not act via this mechanism of action.

B) CORRECT:

Antagonism at leukotriene D4 receptors is the mechanism of action of zafirlukast and montelukast. Antagonized G protein-coupled leukotriene receptors on bronchial smooth muscle cells cannot bind leukotrienes released by inflammatory cells, which results in reduced bronchoconstriction and inflammation. Leukotriene receptor antagonists (LTRAs) are used as a second-line or additional treatment for mild to moderate chronic asthma because they generally have less efficacy than inhaled glucocorticoids and long-acting beta-2 receptor agonists, the former of which, in a low dose, would likely be preferred in this case.

LTRAs tend to function particularly well in a subset of asthma patients who have exercise-induced or aspirin-exacerbated symptoms, or whose exacerbations are triggered by viral infections.
Image Description:

B2-agonists (e.g., salbutamol): relax bronchial smooth muscle and induce bronchodilation

Theophylline: inhibits phosphodiesterase (PDE) and the conversion of cyclic-AMP to AMP, resulting in anti-inflammatory and bronchodilatory effects

Mepolizumab (monoclonal antibody): binds to interleukin-5 and prevents binding to its receptor on eosinophils resulting in reduced eosinophil activation.

Omalizumab (monoclonal antibody): inhibits the binding of IgE and, thus, the activation of mast cells, basophils, and dendritic cells

Mast cell stabilizers (e.g., cromolyn sodium, nedocromil): block the IgE receptor on mast cells preventing degranulation and histamine release

Muscarinic antagonists (e.g., ipratropium bromide): competitively inhibit postganglionic muscarinic receptors in bronchial smooth muscle resulting in bronchodilation

Leukotriene receptor antagonists (LTRA; e.g, montelukast): counteract the pro-inflammatory effects of leukotrienes by blocking the leukotriene receptor on bronchial smooth muscle

Inhaled/oral corticosteroids (e.g., beclomethasone, prednisolone): inhibit transcription factors (e.g., NF-kB), resulting in an anti-inflammatory effect

Zileuton: inhibits 5-lipoxygenase, resulting in reduced leukotriene production

C) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of phosphodiesterase is the mechanism of action of theophylline. Without hydrolysis by phosphodiesterase, intracellular cAMP concentrations increase, which leads to bronchial smooth muscle relaxation and bronchodilation. However, theophylline has a narrow therapeutic index and is associated with significant toxicity (nausea, vomiting, seizures, and cardiac arrhythmias); therefore, theophylline is not often used in children. Zafirlukast does not act on phosphodiesterase.

D) INCORRECT:

Antagonism at muscarinic receptors is the mechanism of action of ipratropium and tiotropium. Muscarinic receptor antagonism alleviates bronchoconstriction and reduces mucus secretion in the respiratory tract. Ipratropium and tiotropium are commonly used to treat acute asthma exacerbations and COPD. However, they are not typically used to treat chronic asthma as seen in this patient. Zafirlukast does not act via this mechanism of action.

E) INCORRECT:

Inactivation of NF-κB is the mechanism of action of glucocorticoids. NF-κB inhibition results in decreased transcription of cytokines and other inflammation-associated molecules; it also inhibits bronchial inflammation by suppressing both B-cell and T-cell function. Low-dose inhaled glucocorticoids are a first-line treatment for mild chronic asthma and would likely be recommended in addition to this patient's albuterol inhaler. However, inactivation of NF-κB is not the mechanism of action of zafirlukast.

F) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of mast cell degranulation is the mechanism of action of cromolyn and nedocromil, both of which are mast cell stabilizers. These agents prevent the release of inflammatory mediators from mast cells, thereby reducing bronchospasms in asthmatics. Zafirlukast, however, does not act via this mechanism of action.

G) INCORRECT:

Blockade of the 5-lipoxygenase pathway is the mechanism of action of zileuton. The drug selectively inhibits the metabolism of arachidonic acid to leukotrienes by 5-lipoxygenase, thereby inhibiting the bronchospastic process initiated by proinflammatory leukotrienes. Zafirlukast, however, does not act via this mechanism of action.
questions.hint: Zafirlukast and montelukast are agents of the same class and are sometimes also used in the treatment of chronic urticaria.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with asthma is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of shortness of breath and cough. Current medications are inhaled albuterol and beclomethasone. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F) and respirations are 24/min. Pulmonary examination shows bilateral expiratory wheezing. Serum studies show increased concentrations of interleukin-5. Which of the following is the most likely effect of the observed laboratory finding in this patient?

choices.text: Differentiation of bone marrow stem cells
Induction of immunoglobulin class switching to IgE
Activation of the classic complement pathway
Suppression of MHC class II expression

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Several chemotactic agents (e.g., leukotriene B4, complement factor 5a, kallikrein, platelet-activating factor, N-formylmethionine, and interleukin-8) promote the migration of neutrophils; interleukin-5 does not play a role in this process.

B) CORRECT:

Interleukin-5 is secreted by Th2 cells and mast cells and promotes the proliferation and activation of eosinophils and B cells. It also promotes immunoglobulin class switching to IgA and plays a role in wound healing.
Image Description:

B2-agonists (e.g., salbutamol): relax bronchial smooth muscle and induce bronchodilation

Theophylline: inhibits phosphodiesterase (PDE) and the conversion of cyclic-AMP to AMP, resulting in anti-inflammatory and bronchodilatory effects

Mepolizumab (monoclonal antibody): binds to interleukin-5 and prevents binding to its receptor on eosinophils resulting in reduced eosinophil activation.

Omalizumab (monoclonal antibody): inhibits the binding of IgE and, thus, the activation of mast cells, basophils, and dendritic cells

Mast cell stabilizers (e.g., cromolyn sodium, nedocromil): block the IgE receptor on mast cells preventing degranulation and histamine release

Muscarinic antagonists (e.g., ipratropium bromide): competitively inhibit postganglionic muscarinic receptors in bronchial smooth muscle resulting in bronchodilation

Leukotriene receptor antagonists (LTRA; e.g, montelukast): counteract the pro-inflammatory effects of leukotrienes by blocking the leukotriene receptor on bronchial smooth muscle

Inhaled/oral corticosteroids (e.g., beclomethasone, prednisolone): inhibit transcription factors (e.g., NF-kB), resulting in an anti-inflammatory effect

Zileuton: inhibits 5-lipoxygenase, resulting in reduced leukotriene production

C) INCORRECT:

Interleukin-3 is secreted by activated B cells and T cells and promotes the proliferation and differentiation of bone marrow stem cells. Interleukin-3 also promotes the proliferation of granulocytes in the bone marrow and lymphocytes in the spleen. Interleukin-5 does not play a role in the differentiation of bone marrow stem cells.

D) INCORRECT:

Several cytokines (e.g., interleukin-1, interleukin-6, and TNF-α) promote the secretion of acute phase reactants; interleukin-5 does not play a role in this process.

E) INCORRECT:

Interleukin-4 is secreted by Th2 cells and promotes immunoglobulin class switching to IgE. Interleukin-4 also promotes immunoglobulin class switching to IgG, promotes the growth of B cells, induces proliferation of mast cells and basophils, and induces differentiation of T cells into Th2 cells. Interleukin-5 does not play a role in immunoglobulin class switching to IgE.

F) INCORRECT:

The classical complement pathway is activated by antigen-antibody complexes; interleukin-5 does not play a role in this process.

G) INCORRECT:

Interleukin-10 is secreted by T cells and macrophages and suppresses MHC class II expression. Interleukin-10 also suppresses Th1 cytokine expression and inhibits activated macrophages, dendritic cells, and the inflammatory response. Interleukin-5 does not play a role in the suppression of MHC class II expression.
questions.hint: The formation of Charcot-Leyden crystals in the sputum of patients with allergic asthma is a result of the activity of interleukin-5.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of episodic shortness of breath. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show elevated serum IgE levels. Microscopic examination of the sputum shows eosinophilic, hexagonal, double-pointed crystals. A methacholine challenge test is positive. Exposure to which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bird droppings can cause an immune-mediated inflammatory response in the alveoli and small airways, which can manifest with shortness of breath that is similar to asthma. Exposure to bird droppings has been implicated in hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP) and extrinsic allergic alveolitis, but not allergic asthma. HP is not associated with elevated IgE levels or Charcot-Leyden crystals in sputum.

B) INCORRECT:

Aspirin can cause exacerbations of bronchial asthma because it inhibits cyclooxygenase, resulting in increased leukotriene synthesis, which causes bronchoconstriction. However, aspirin has been implicated in exacerbations of intrinsic asthma, not allergic asthma. Intrinsic asthma is not associated with elevated IgE levels or Charcot-Leyden crystals in sputum.

C) INCORRECT:

Cold air can cause exacerbations of bronchial asthma because it irritates the airways. However, cold air is implicated in exacerbations of intrinsic asthma, not allergic asthma. Intrinsic asthma is not associated with elevated IgE levels or Charcot-Leyden crystals in sputum.

D) INCORRECT:

Viral pathogens can cause exacerbations of bronchial asthma by causing inflammation (virus-induced exacerbations). However, viral infections have been implicated in exacerbations of intrinsic asthma, not allergic asthma. Intrinsic asthma is not associated with elevated IgE levels or Charcot-Leyden crystals in sputum.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's history of episodic dyspnea in conjunction with elevated IgE levels and Charcot-Leyden crystals suggest extrinsic asthma (allergic asthma), an IgE-mediated type 1 hypersensitivity reaction to specific allergens. Common environmental allergens that can trigger allergic asthma include dust mites, pollen, domestic animals, and mold spores.

F) INCORRECT:

Tobacco smoke inhalation can cause exacerbations of bronchial asthma because it irritates the airways and causes damage to cilia. However, tobacco smoke has been implicated in exacerbations of intrinsic asthma, not allergic asthma. Intrinsic asthma is not associated with elevated IgE levels or Charcot-Leyden crystals in sputum.
questions.hint: This patient's sputum shows Charcot-Leyden crystals (eosinophilic, hexagonal, double-pointed crystals).

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-week history of intermittent shortness of breath and a dry cough that is worse at night. He had an upper respiratory tract infection 3 weeks ago. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Spirometry shows normal forced vital capacity and peak expiratory flow rate. The physician administers a drug, after which repeat spirometry shows a reduced peak expiratory flow rate. Which of the following drugs was most likely administered?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Atenolol is a beta blocker that is selective for beta-1 receptors, which are present mainly in cardiac tissue. Therefore, atenolol would have minimal effect on bronchial reactivity. Non-selective beta blockers, however, target beta-1 receptors and beta-2 receptors, the latter of which are found in bronchial tissue. These medications can lead to bronchial hyperreactivity as well as bronchospasm, so they should be used with caution in patients with asthma.

B) CORRECT:

Methacholine, a non-selective M3 muscarinic agonist, was most likely administered to this patient whose repeat spirometry shows a reduction in peak expiratory flow rate. Asthma is a dynamic airway disease, and symptoms may only occur in the presence of a trigger (e.g., pollen, pet dander, or smoke). In patients that have suggestive symptoms (e.g., intermittent shortness of breath) but normal pulmonary function tests, bronchoprovocative testing can be helpful in confirming a diagnosis of asthma. Bronchoprovocative testing uses methacholine to induce bronchoconstriction during spirometry, resulting in reduced FEV1 and peak expiratory flow rate.

The methacholine challenge test has a low specificity but high sensitivity in confirming the diagnosis of asthma in children.

C) INCORRECT:

Ipratropium bromide competitively blocks muscarinic receptors and prevents bronchoconstriction. This drug is used in maintenance therapy to reduce obstructive airway symptoms in patients with asthma and COPD. Ipratropium bromide would not worsen pulmonary function tests in a patient with obstructive airway disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Albuterol, a short-acting beta-2 agonist, relaxes bronchial smooth muscle and so induces bronchodilation. This drug is used in the treatment of acute asthma exacerbations and would improve spirometry measurements during pulmonary function testing, unlike the drug in question, which worsens the spirometry metrics.

E) INCORRECT:

Methoxyflurane is an inhaled anesthetic that causes short-acting sedation and analgesia. It is used at low doses as a nonopiod analgesic. Side effects include CNS and respiratory depression. It does not induce bronchoconstriction in patients with reactive airway disease and would not be used in bronchial challenge testing.

F) INCORRECT:

Epinephrine, a sympathomimetic agent, causes bronchial smooth muscle relaxation. It is used in the treatment of acute asthma exacerbation. Epinephrine would not worsen pulmonary function tests in a patient with obstructive airway disease.
questions.hint: This test evaluates the presence of airway hyperresponsiveness.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her father because of a dry cough, nasal congestion, and intermittent wheezing during the past 2 months. Since birth, she has had four upper respiratory tract infections that resolved without treatment and one episode of acute otitis media treated with antibiotics. She has a history of eczema. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.7°F) and respirations are 24/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Physical examination shows a shallow breathing pattern and scattered expiratory wheezing throughout both lung fields. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in diagnosing this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A methacholine challenge test can be used to diagnose asthma if the initial test of choice is inconclusive. However, bronchoprovocation tests run an inherent, if minimal, risk of inducing a life-threatening asthma attack. While a methacholine challenge test is effective for determining both the hyperresponsiveness of airways and the reversibility of the obstruction found in asthma, a different, less risky test is indicated as the initial diagnostic step. In addition, a negative methacholine challenge test can reliably exclude asthma.

B) INCORRECT:

An arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis can be a useful tool for assessing the severity of an asthma attack, gauging the patient's response to initial treatment, and guiding further treatment plans. In this case, however, the patient has normal oxygen saturation on room air, which indicates that she is not currently experiencing an acute asthma exacerbation. Moreover, ABGs are not used to diagnose asthma.

C) INCORRECT:

In patients with suspected asthma who are unresponsive to initial therapy, chest x-ray is helpful for ruling out alternative diagnoses, such as pneumothorax or pneumonia. However, a chest x-ray is not the best initial diagnostic step for establishing a diagnosis. Moreover, chest x-ray findings are typically normal in patients with asthma, except in severe cases where signs of lung hyperinflation are seen (e.g., flattened diaphragmatic contours, horizontalization of ribs, increased anteroposterior diameter of the chest, hyperlucent lungs).

D) INCORRECT:

Serum IgE levels may be elevated in patients with atopy and asthma. While IgE plays an important role in the pathogenesis of asthma, a significant correlation between serum IgE levels and the likelihood of developing asthma has not been established. Moreover, serum IgE levels are neither sensitive nor specific for diagnosing asthma.

E) CORRECT:

Spirometry is the initial test of choice for diagnosing asthma in patients ≥ 5 years of age. Decreased FEV1 and an FEV1/FVC ratio less than 0.7 are consistent with obstructive lung disease. Additionally, classic “scooping” during expiration seen on the flow-volume loop can help distinguish asthma from other illnesses of airflow limitation (i.e., fixed obstruction, paradoxical vocal fold motion). If an obstructive pattern is seen on spirometry, reversal with the administration of bronchodilators (FEV1 and/or FVC increase of ≥ 12% and at least 200 mL) confirms the diagnosis of asthma.
Image Description:

Expiratory flow is impaired by narrowed airways. Therefore, the peak expiratory flow rate is lower than normal with a slightly concave (scooped) curve toward the residual volume. The residual volume is abnormally high (∼ 2 L), as the narrowed airways have prevented a full expiration.
questions.hint: A chronic cough and intermittent wheezing with a history of atopy suggest a diagnosis of asthma.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 6-month history of episodic dry cough, shortness of breath, and chest tightness. She has seasonal allergic rhinitis. Physical examination shows high-pitched expiratory wheezes throughout both lung fields. Pulmonary function testing shows an FEV1 of 70% (N ≥ 80%). Which of the following drugs would be most effective at reducing bronchial inflammation in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Salmeterol is an inhaled beta-2 adrenergic agonist used to treat moderate to severe asthma. This drug activates Gs protein-coupled receptors, which results in hyperpolarization of smooth muscle cells of the airways and bronchodilation. Salmeterol does not have a significant antiinflammatory effect.

B) INCORRECT:

Theophylline inhibits phosphodiesterase activity in cells, which increases cAMP levels. This results in hyperpolarization of smooth muscle cells in the lungs, which causes bronchodilation. Although this drug has some antiinflammatory properties, it is not the most effective drug that reduces bronchial inflammation in patients with asthma.

C) INCORRECT:

Tiotropium is an inhaled antimuscarinic agent that primarily inhibits M3 receptors on smooth muscle cells and submucosal glands. This results in a decrease of Gq protein-coupled receptor activity, which reduces smooth muscle contraction and mucous gland secretions to improve airflow. Tiotropium does not have a significant antiinflammatory effect.

D) INCORRECT:

Montelukast inhibits the action of leukotriene D4, which results in decreased bronchoconstriction. Although this drug has some antiinflammatory properties, it is not the most effective drug that reduces bronchial inflammation in patients with asthma.

E) CORRECT:

Inhaled corticosteroids such as budesonide are used as first-line treatment in patients with persistent asthma. This class of drug binds to glucocorticoid nuclear receptors, which leads to increased expression of antiinflammatory molecules (e.g., lipocortin-1) and decreased expression of inflammatory molecules (e.g., cyclooxygenases). The resulting decrease in bronchial inflammation reduces submucosal edema and bronchoconstriction with consequent relief of asthma-induced bronchial obstruction.
Image Description:

B2-agonists (e.g., salbutamol): relax bronchial smooth muscle and induce bronchodilation

Theophylline: inhibits phosphodiesterase (PDE) and the conversion of cyclic-AMP to AMP, resulting in anti-inflammatory and bronchodilatory effects

Mepolizumab (monoclonal antibody): binds to interleukin-5 and prevents binding to its receptor on eosinophils resulting in reduced eosinophil activation.

Omalizumab (monoclonal antibody): inhibits the binding of IgE and, thus, the activation of mast cells, basophils, and dendritic cells

Mast cell stabilizers (e.g., cromolyn sodium, nedocromil): block the IgE receptor on mast cells preventing degranulation and histamine release

Muscarinic antagonists (e.g., ipratropium bromide): competitively inhibit postganglionic muscarinic receptors in bronchial smooth muscle resulting in bronchodilation

Leukotriene receptor antagonists (LTRA; e.g, montelukast): counteract the pro-inflammatory effects of leukotrienes by blocking the leukotriene receptor on bronchial smooth muscle

Inhaled/oral corticosteroids (e.g., beclomethasone, prednisolone): inhibit transcription factors (e.g., NF-kB), resulting in an anti-inflammatory effect

Zileuton: inhibits 5-lipoxygenase, resulting in reduced leukotriene production
questions.hint: This patient's persistent symptoms (cough, wheezing, dyspnea, and chest tightness) for 6 months, history of allergic rhinitis, and spirometry findings (decreased FEV1) make asthma the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: Forty minutes after undergoing nasal polypectomy for refractory rhinitis, a 48-year-old woman develops chest tightness and shortness of breath. The surgical course was uncomplicated, and the patient was successfully extubated. She received ketorolac for postoperative pain. A similar episode happened 6 months ago after the patient took aspirin for a headache; symptoms resolved spontaneously within 3 hours. She has a history of asthma and hypertension. Her daily medications include metoprolol and lisinopril. Examination shows a flushed face, watery rhinorrhea, and conjunctival injection. Chest auscultation reveals bilateral wheezing and decreased breath sounds. An ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A type 1 hypersensitivity reaction causes bronchospasm and facial flushing. However, watery rhinorrhea and conjunctival injection are not expected. These features combined with chronic rhinosinusitis, nasal polyposis, NSAID hypersensitivity, and asthma make another underlying cause more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Prinzmetal angina typically manifests as periodic episodes of chest tightness and ischemic ECG changes are usually present during these episodes. However, this patient's ECG is normal. Moreover, clinical features of bronchospasm (e.g., wheezing with decreased breath sounds), a history of aspirin allergy, nasal polyps, and the onset of symptoms following the administration of ketorolac indicate a different diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

Samter triad is a feature of aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD). Patients with AERD develop symptoms resembling those of a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction (e.g., wheezing, decreased breath sounds, facial flushing) following the administration of aspirin or NSAIDs (e.g., ketorolac). Watery rhinorrhea and conjunctival injection are also commonly seen in AERD. Unlike a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction, which is an IgE-mediated process, AERD is a pseudoallergic reaction caused by the inhibition of cyclooxygenase (COX). Inhibition of the COX pathway increases the conversion of arachidonic acid to leukotrienes via the lipoxygenases pathway. Leukotrienes cause cutaneous flushing and bronchial inflammation.

D) INCORRECT:

The use of nonselective beta blockers can result in bronchospasm due to inhibition of β2 receptors on the bronchial wall. However, metoprolol is a beta blocker that selectively inhibits β1 receptors. It is therefore not the most likely cause of bronchospasm in this patient.

All beta blockers can trigger bronchospasms in patients with asthma and β1-receptor selectivity is diminished in higher doses. Therefore, beta blockers should be avoided in patients with severe or decompensated asthma. However, therapeutic doses of cardioselective beta blockers are generally well tolerated in patients with mild to moderate asthma.

E) INCORRECT:

ACE inhibitors such as lisinopril can cause accumulation of bradykinin, which can result in a flushed face (due to angioedema) and wheezing due to the bronchoconstrictive effect of bradykinin. However, a history of aspirin allergy, nasal polyps, and the onset of symptoms following the administration of ketorolac suggest a different mechanism for bronchospasm.
questions.hint: Chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyposis, NSAID hypersensitivity, and asthma constitutes Samter triad.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought by her parents to the physician because of recurrent episodes of shortness of breath and nonproductive cough over the past 3 months. She has had episodes of shortness of breath almost daily, which have resolved spontaneously with rest. She wakes up at night with shortness of breath at least once a week. Spirometry shows an FVC of 85% and an FEV1 of 79% of predicted. Treatment with inhaled budesonide-formoterol is begun. Two weeks later, she is brought to the physician with acute onset of dyspnea and wheezing. Her pulse is 95/min and respirations are 32/min. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Salmeterol is a long-acting inhaled beta-2 adrenergic agonist that is indicated in the long-term management of asthma to help decrease the number and severity of exacerbations. This medication is not effective for relieving acute exacerbations because of its delayed onset of action.

B) INCORRECT:

Although cromolyn sodium, a mast cell stabilizer, was previously used as an alternative to corticosteroids for the long-term control of persistent asthma, it is not effective for treating acute exacerbations.

C) CORRECT:

Albuterol is an inhaled, short-acting beta-2 adrenergic agonist and is the treatment of choice for acute asthma symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Guaifenesin, which is an expectorant, is used in acute exacerbations of chronic bronchitis. Chronic bronchitis can cause episodes of shortness of breath and cough but chronic bronchitis typically occurs in smokers and the cough associated with chronic bronchitis would be productive. Guaifenesin is not used to treat bronchial asthma.

E) INCORRECT:

Montelukast, a leukotriene-receptor antagonist, is used for long-term control of persistent asthma when a noncorticosteroid therapeutic alternative is desired. It has no significant efficacy in controlling acute exacerbations.

F) INCORRECT:

Fluticasone is an inhaled corticosteroid that can be used in the long-term management of asthma because it reduces the frequency and severity of exacerbations. However, fluticasone is long acting and typically only reaches peak effect after several days to weeks. This patient requires urgent relief for her asthma symptoms.
questions.hint: In a patient with a history of asthma, acute-onset dyspnea and wheezing in combination with increased respiratory rate is consistent with an acute asthma exacerbation.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of severe shortness of breath and dry cough for 30 minutes. The symptoms started while she participated in a soccer tournament at her school. Her father was diagnosed with asthma as a child. Her pulse is 130/min and respirations are 35/min. Treatment with inhaled albuterol is initiated. A physician administers a second drug to increase the action of albuterol on bronchial smooth muscle cell receptors. Which of the following drugs is most likely to have had this effect?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous magnesium sulfate increases smooth muscle dilation in intermediate and small airways. This drug is indicated for patients with a life-threatening asthma exacerbation, as seen here, to reduce the severity of respiratory distress. However, it does not demonstrate a permissive effect on albuterol.

B) CORRECT:

Steroids (e.g., prednisolone, dexamethasone) demonstrate a permissive drug interaction with adrenergic receptor agonists (e.g., albuterol), thereby increasing the amplitude of the maximal response to adrenergic agonists. Steroids accomplish this by increasing adrenergic receptor activation and the concentration of signaling intermediates (e.g., cyclic AMP). They demonstrate a dose-dependent response, meaning that the amplitude of the maximal activation increases as the steroid concentration increases. Systemic steroids are therefore often used in patients with severe asthma exacerbations to increase the therapeutic effect of albuterol on respiratory distress. They are also used to increase the potency of adrenergic agonists in patients with anaphylaxis or severe shock.

C) INCORRECT:

Theophylline inhibits phosphodiesterase; it primarily has an antiinflammatory effect, and to a lesser extent it facilitates bronchodilation. It was previously used as adjuvant therapy to prevent asthma exacerbations, but is no longer routinely used due to side effects. In addition, theophylline does not have a permissive effect on albuterol.

D) INCORRECT:

Cromolyn sodium prevents mast cells from releasing inflammatory mediators that stimulate bronchoconstriction. It was previously used as a preventive treatment in patients with asthma prior to exercise or unavoidable exposure to known allergens, but it is no longer recommended. In addition, it does not have a permissive effect on albuterol, and it is not administered in acute asthma exacerbations.

E) INCORRECT:

Montelukast noncompetitively inhibits leukotriene receptors (CysLT1) and thereby reduces bronchoconstriction and airway inflammation. This drug is prescribed as an alternative long-term treatment option for exercise-induced asthma and aspirin-induced asthma. It does not have a permissive effect on albuterol, and it is not administered in acute asthma exacerbations.

F) INCORRECT:

Aerosolized ipratropium bromide is indicated for patients with a severe asthma exacerbation, which this patient has, to reduce the severity of respiratory distress. Ipratropium bromide competitively inhibits postganglionic muscarinic receptors in bronchial smooth muscles, thereby facilitating the dilation of intermediate and small airways. However, it does not have a permissive effect on albuterol.
questions.hint: The second drug is required for albuterol to exert its full effect on its target receptor, a phenomenon called permissiveness.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a 2-month history of intermittent wheezing and nonproductive cough. Her symptoms worsened after she and her family moved to the countryside 1 month ago. The child has a history of atopic dermatitis. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 29/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Bilateral scattered wheezes are heard on auscultation of the chest. Pulmonary function testing is most likely to show which of the following sets of findings?



FEV1

FVC
DLCO

Total lung capacity



A
Decreased
normal
decreased
increased


B
Decreased
decreased
normal
decreased


C
Decreased
decreased
decreased
decreased


D
Normal
normal
decreased
normal


E
Decreased
normal
increased
increased
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This set of findings is compatible with emphysema, a form of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Emphysema decreases the surface area available for gaseous exchange, resulting in decreased DLCO. COPD can also manifest with wheezing, an obstructive pattern on pulmonary function tests including decreased FEV1, and, in the case of air trapping, increased total lung capacity with normal or decreased FVC. Although early-onset emphysema can occur in patients with certain rare hereditary disorders (e.g., alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency), this young girl most likely has bronchial asthma rather than COPD.

B) INCORRECT:

This set of findings is compatible with restrictive lung disease (RLD) due to extrapulmonary causes (e.g., obesity, neuromuscular disease, thoracic deformities). FEV1, FVC, and total lung capacity (TLC) are decreased but DLCO is typically normal, as the intrinsic quality of the lung is not affected. In RLD due to extrapulmonary causes, the FEV1:FVC ratio is typically normal because FVC and FEV1 decrease in equal proportion.

C) INCORRECT:

This set of findings is compatible with restrictive lung disease (RLD) caused by intrinsic lung impairment (e.g., interstitial lung disease, pneumonia, pulmonary edema). All lung volumes and capacities, including FEV1, FVC, and total lung capacity, are decreased as a result of the lungs' impaired ability to expand (decreased compliance). In RLD caused by intrinsic lung impairment, the FEV1:FVC ratio is normal or increased because the decrease in FVC is more substantial than the decrease in FEV1. Additionally, DLCO is decreased because the surface area for gaseous exchange is diminished.

D) INCORRECT:

This set of findings is compatible with primary pulmonary vascular disease (e.g., pulmonary embolism, idiopathic pulmonary hypertension), severe anemia, and carboxyhemoglobinemia (e.g., in smokers, carbon monoxide poisoning). As these conditions do not cause a restrictive or obstructive pattern, lung volumes and capacities are not affected. These conditions instead decrease lung perfusion, resulting in decreased DLCO.

E) CORRECT:

This set of findings is consistent with BA. FEV1 decreases as a result of increased airway resistance (due to airway narrowing). Total lung capacity (TLC) and FVC can be normal but in the case of severe BA, air trapping occurs, resulting in increased residual volume and increased TLC; FVC might also decrease if air trapping is severe. In BA, the diffusion capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide (DLCO) is normal or increased. The increase in DLCO is thought to be due to a combination of increased pulmonary capillary bed recruitment and increases in alveolar pressure and/or surface area (as a result of air trapping and hyperinflation). In BA and other obstructive lung diseases (e.g., chronic obstructive pulmonary disease), the FEV1:FVC ratio is typically decreased because the decrease in FEV1 is more substantial than the decrease in FVC.

Pulmonary function tests (PFTs), such as spirometry and single-breath diffusion capacity (DLCO measurement), can be performed in children who are able to understand and follow instructions for breathing maneuvers (typically children older than 5 years of age). Spirometry is used to determine the severity of BA and to guide therapy.
questions.hint: In a patient with a history of atopy, wheezing and nonproductive cough that worsened after probable exposure to allergens (the family moved to the countryside) are suggestive of bronchial asthma (BA).

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of recurrent episodes of shortness of breath, chest tightness, and nonproductive cough that first started about 4 months ago. He says these episodes usually occur during or shortly after soccer practice and resolve spontaneously when he stops exercising. He has no shortness of breath at other times, including at night. His sister has allergic rhinitis. His pulse is 68/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Spirometry shows a FEV1/FVC ratio of 0.88 and an FEV1 of 91% of predicted. Bronchodilator responsiveness testing is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Skin prick testing can be used to identify allergens that trigger allergic asthma. This patient, however, has no history of allergic conditions (e.g., atopy), and his clinical presentation (i.e., symptoms provoked during or after exercise) suggests exercise-induced bronchoconstriction.

B) INCORRECT:

Single-breath diffusing capacity (DLCO) is usually performed to differentiate between intrapulmonary and extrapulmonary causes of restrictive lung disease or hypoxemia that remain unexplained even after spirometry. Since this patient has normal spirometry findings and no hypoxemia, another test should be performed to diagnose his condition.

C) INCORRECT:

A chest x-ray can be useful in severe cases of asthma to evaluate for signs of lung hyperinflation (e.g., flattened diaphragmatic contours, hyperlucent lungs) or to rule out alternative diagnoses, such as pneumothorax or pneumonia. This patient's clinical presentation suggests exercise-induced bronchoconstriction, in which chest x-ray findings would be normal.

D) INCORRECT:
