Eosinophils and total IgE concentration may be elevated in patients with atopy, certain infections, and allergic asthma. This patient has no history of allergies or infection, and total IgE concentration and eosinophil count are neither sensitive nor specific for such conditions. Moreover, this patient's clinical presentation (i.e., symptoms provoked during or after exercise) suggests exercise-induced bronchoconstriction.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's spirometry findings show only mild reductions in FEV1 and FEV1/FVC ratio, and bronchodilator responsiveness testing is negative. However, this patient presents with features of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction, making another step in diagnosis more appropriate.

F) CORRECT:

Exercise is a trigger of bronchoconstriction, which typically occurs in individuals with underlying asthma. A methacholine challenge test is a type of bronchial provocation test used to diagnose exercise-induced bronchoconstriction in patients with inconclusive spirometry findings. Although a methacholine challenge test is effective for determining both the hyperresponsiveness of airways and the reversibility of the obstruction, it should be carried out carefully because of its inherent but minimal risk of inducing a life-threatening asthma attack.

An exercise challenge test is the method of choice for the definitive diagnosis of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction.
questions.hint: This patient has shortness of breath, nonproductive cough, chest tightness while exercising, and normal spirometry findings, all of which suggest exercise-induced bronchoconstriction.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 12 years
Sex assigned at birth: F
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: ”My daughter can't get rid of this cough.”
History of Present Illness:

patient brought to the office by her mother

10-month history of dry cough and nasal congestion that started in March
symptoms are present nearly every day but are worse during weekdays and improve slightly over the weekend
reports an unrepaired water leak from an air conditioning unit in her classroom and similar symptoms among several classmates

Past Medical History:
no serious illness
Medications:
none
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:
no similar symptoms in her family
Psychosocial History:

lives with parents, 16-year-old brother, and 1-year-old sister in Florida
participates in the school basketball team; has intensified training since last year, currently practicing 4 afternoons every week;  does 5k runs with her brother on the weekends

Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI


37.1°C(98.8°F)
82/min
18/min
123/75 mm Hg
98% on RA
155 cm (5 ft 1 in)55th %ile
45 kg (99 lb)57th %ile
19 kg/m259th %ile



Appearance: alert; intermittent dry cough
Skin: no rashes
HEENT: PERRLA; normal conjunctivae and oropharynx; pale nasal mucosa; hypertrophic turbinates

Pulmonary: scattered expiratory wheezing

Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs; capillary refill < 2 seconds

Extremities: no joint swelling, edema, or tenderness

Diagnostic Studies

spirometry: FEV1/FVC ratio of 0.65
chest x-ray: no abnormalities


Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although pollen is a common trigger of allergic asthma and allergic rhinitis, and some pollens (e.g., alder and hazel tree pollen) start to appear as early as March, pollen-induced allergy typically has a seasonal pattern. This patient's symptoms have lasted nearly a year and improve on weekends, which makes another cause more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhalation of aerosols from air conditioners (e.g., at school) with water contaminated by Legionella pneumophila, a gram-negative bacteria, can cause outbreaks of legionellosis, which manifests as self-limiting Pontiac fever with flu-like symptoms, or as Legionnaires' disease with atypical pneumonia and additional gastrointestinal and neurological symptoms (e.g., diarrhea, confusion). This patient has no gastrointestinal or neurological symptoms, and her respiratory symptoms have continued for nearly a year. Furthermore, if this patient had legionellosis, her symptoms would not improve on weekends.

C) INCORRECT:

Symptoms of exercise-induced asthma are triggered shortly after the onset of intense exercise and can persist for up to one hour after its completion. Although this patient's symptoms worsen in the afternoons during basketball training, she does not report asthmatic symptoms during her weekend runs.

D) CORRECT:

Allergic asthma, the most common type of asthma, is an IgE-mediated type I hypersensitivity reaction to specific allergens and is commonly associated with other atopic conditions such as allergic rhinitis. The most frequently implicated allergens include pollen, dust mites, mold, and animal dander. Pollen-induced allergies are typically seasonal, whereas allergies caused by indoor exposure to dust mites, mold, or animal dander are usually perennial and linked to repeated exposure at home, school, or the workplace. Certain species of mold are associated with an increased risk of allergic asthma (e.g., Aspergillus), and exposure to mold spores typically occurs in damp environments (e.g., due to a water leak). Occasionally, especially in colder regions of the U.S., mold-induced allergies may display a seasonal pattern because mold growth increases during periods of heightened moisture. Management of allergic asthma involves stepwise asthma treatment and avoidance of environmental triggers.

E) INCORRECT:

Viral upper respiratory tract infection (URTI) can cause an outbreak in a school and is a typical trigger of nonallergic asthma in children. However, viral URTI typically resolves within 1–2 weeks, whereas this patient has had symptoms for nearly a year.
questions.hint: This patient has features of asthma (persistent dry cough, expiratory wheezing, obstructive pattern on spirometry) and chronic rhinitis (hypertrophic turbinates).

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravid woman at 24 weeks' gestation comes to the office because of a 1-month history of worsening episodes of shortness of breath and nonproductive cough. The episodes occur approximately 3 times per week during housework and her walks outside and resolve with her albuterol rescue inhaler. Over the past month, she has also experienced 4 episodes of shortness of breath at night, which woke her up from her sleep. Pregnancy has been uncomplicated. Medical history is remarkable for intermittent asthma, which had been well controlled with inhaled albuterol as needed. Other medications include prenatal vitamins. She appears well. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 17/min and blood pressure is 122/84 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air discloses an oxygen saturation of 97%. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Fetal heart rate is 146/min. Spirometry shows an FEV1 of 85% predicted. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Switch from inhaled albuterol to oral montelukast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

There is evidence supporting that vitamin D supplementation during pregnancy may reduce the risk of childhood asthma in the offspring. Vitamin D supplementation should be considered in pregnant women at high risk of having a child with asthma (i.e., a history of asthma in one or both parents). However, high-dose, and not low-dose, supplementation is advised. Moreover, in this patient, asthma control should be prioritized as poorly controlled asthma in the mother is also a risk factor for childhood asthma in the offspring.

B) INCORRECT:

Although oral montelukast can be used to help prevent exacerbations, all patients with asthma should receive asthma reliever therapy (e.g., short-acting beta agonist, ICS/formoterol). Furthermore, this patient currently needs to use her asthma reliever daily, and discontinuation of albuterol is therefore inappropriate.

C) CORRECT:

Asthma symptoms may be worse, better, or unchanged during pregnancy. Inhaled corticosteroids (e.g., budesonide) are indicated in patients with mild persistent asthma to reduce exacerbations and can be combined with short-acting beta-2 agonists (e.g., albuterol) as needed for symptom relief. Poorly controlled asthma can increase the risk of pregnancy complications, and the benefit of asthma control outweighs the potential adverse risks of asthma medications. Therefore, the same approach to management as with nonpregnant patients is indicated to optimize both maternal and fetal health. During pregnancy, budesonide is the preferred inhaled corticosteroid, and inhalation treatments are preferred because of fewer systemic side effects.

See “Stepwise pharmacological treatment of chronic asthma” table.

D) INCORRECT:

Identification and control of environmental triggers are essential components in managing asthma patients to reduce the frequency of acute exacerbations and the need for pharmacologic therapy. However, in this patient with mild persistent asthma, pharmacological treatment is indicated; control of environmental triggers only would not be appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Systemic glucocorticoids (e.g., oral methylprednisolone) are reserved for patients with acute asthma exacerbations or severe persistent asthma and should only be used during pregnancy when indicated. In this patient, however, oral methylprednisolone is not indicated as symptoms resolve with the use of a short-acting beta-2 agonist. Additionally, systemic glucocorticoids used for asthma management during pregnancy increase the risk of congenital malformations (e.g., cleft palate), preeclampsia, low birth weight, and neonatal adrenal insufficiency.
questions.hint: Shortness of breath and nonproductive cough that worsens with exercise are consistent with asthma. Symptom frequency and use of albuterol inhaler > 2 times/week, waking up because of symptoms 3–4 times/month, and an FEV1 within the normal range meet the criteria for mild persistent asthma.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man with asthma, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes who has never smoked presents for routine evaluation. He has been using inhaled budesonide-formoterol as needed during the day four to five times per week and at night once a week. His symptoms are typically brought on by cold air and exercise. He states that he does not experience allergy symptoms.
On examination, he has a respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 96% while he is breathing ambient air. He has scattered wheezes but no accessory muscle usage.
A chest radiograph is unremarkable.
The patient’s peak flow reading is 550 liters/minute; his best peak flow recorded is 620 liters/minute.
Which one of the following medications would be most appropriate to reduce this patient’s daily symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients whose asthma symptoms persist despite use of as-needed inhaled glucocorticoid-formoterol require a step-up in therapy. Guidelines from both GINA and the NAEPP recommend transitioning to daily low-dose inhaled glucocorticoid-formoterol. Increasing to a high-dose inhaled glucocorticoid would be a later step in therapy in both guidelines.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral glucocorticoids may be used for acute exacerbations or for very severe disease that has failed step-up therapy. These agents can substantially increase glucose levels and are optimally avoided, when possible, in patients with type 2 diabetes.

C) INCORRECT:

Omalizumab may be considered in patients whose allergy symptoms persist despite treatment with an inhaled glucocorticoid.

D) INCORRECT:

Long-acting beta-agonists (LABAs), such as formoterol and salmeterol, have been associated with increased mortality when used without an inhaled glucocorticoid and therefore should not be used alone. In addition, salmeterol is not an appropriate LABA in a combination inhaler used on an as-needed basis because it does not have rapid-onset activity like formoterol does.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with intermittent asthma symptoms require only an as-needed medication, and the preferred medication in that setting, according to current guidelines from the Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA), is low-dose inhaled glucocorticoid-formoterol. The most recent update of the National Asthma Education and Prevention Program (NAEPP) guidelines recommends starting with an as-needed short-acting beta-agonist and then stepping up to either as-needed low-dose inhaled glucocorticoid-formoterol or a daily low-dose inhaled glucocorticoid. Recent studies have shown that an as-needed glucocorticoid-formoterol inhaler is equivalent to a daily inhaled glucocorticoid in preventing exacerbations but is not as good at daily control of symptoms.

See “Stepwise asthma treatment” table.

Key learning point: In a patient who has persistent asthma symptoms despite an as-needed glucocorticoid-formoterol inhaler, the most appropriate next step in therapy is daily use of a low-dose glucocorticoid-formoterol inhaler.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman who has never smoked presents for evaluation of worsening dyspnea and wheezing during the past several months. She was diagnosed with asthma 5 years ago. Her asthma regimen consists of daily low-dose inhaled fluticasone and an albuterol inhaler, which she uses twice weekly for daytime symptoms brought on by exercise. She reports no symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux, allergies, or postnasal drip. She reports waking up at night with symptoms of dyspnea and wheezing once per week.
On examination, she appears well without respiratory distress. Her oxygen saturation is 93% while she is breathing ambient air. Her cardiac and lung examinations are unremarkable. She has no lower-extremity edema.
A chest radiograph is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following medication changes is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Increase the dose of inhaled fluticasone

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A patient who is currently on a low-dose inhaled glucocorticoid should add a long-acting beta-agonist (LABA), such as inhaled salmeterol, before increasing the dose of the glucocorticoid.

B) CORRECT:

In patients with asthma who are using a short-acting beta-agonist more than twice per week or having nocturnal symptoms more than twice per month, a step-up in medications is recommended.

A patient who is currently on a low-dose inhaled glucocorticoid should add a long-acting beta-agonist (LABA), such as inhaled salmeterol, before increasing the dose of the glucocorticoid. In many cases, switching to a combination inhaler that uses formoterol as the LABA would make sense because formoterol has both long- and short-acting bronchodilator effects. This approach would allow the patient to use the same inhaler as both a maintenance medication and a rescue inhaler.

A stepwise approach to asthma treatment is recommended by the National Asthma Education and Prevention Program (NAEPP) and the Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA). See “Stepwise asthma treatment” table.

Key learning point: The next step in treating a patient who has persistent asthma symptoms despite daily use of a low-dose inhaled glucocorticoid is to add an inhaled long-acting beta-agonist.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral theophylline has a substantial number of adverse effects and is considered a third-line treatment after the addition of a LABA; it may also be used in patients who cannot tolerate LABAs.

D) INCORRECT:

Omalizumab is useful in patients with asthma that is associated with allergy symptoms, but the drug is otherwise not recommended in routine step-up therapy. There are other biologic treatments that could be considered for this patient if she has persistent symptoms despite continued step-ups in her therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral prednisone is a key treatment in patients with acute asthma attacks; however, prolonged use is not recommended because of the drug’s adverse effects. In rare cases, it is used as a chronic medication in very severe asthma, but this decision warrants consultation with an asthma specialist (pulmonologist or allergist) and consideration of a biologic agent first.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman presents with persistent and worsening shortness of breath, cough, and wheezing on exertion. She reports that she has had asthma symptoms for years, with seasonal changes in the past 2 to 3 weeks.
She has had allergic and pulmonary symptoms on and off throughout her life, but in the past few years, standard therapies (inhaled fluticasone-salmeterol, albuterol, tiotropium, and montelukast) have not prevented her from requiring intermittent visits to the emergency department (ED) for symptom flares. Treatment in the ED has consisted of nebulizers and short courses of prednisone. The patient has also been treated for thrush in the past 6 months.
Prior evaluations demonstrate positive skin testing against dust mites and an immunoglobulin E level of 508 IU/mL (reference range, 10–179).
Pulmonary function testing reveals a FEV1 of 65% of predicted and an FEV1 /FVC ratio of 60%.
A chest radiograph is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following therapies is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ipratropium nebulizers are not likely to be more effective than inhaled tiotropium in this clinical context.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhaled DNase is effective in treating cystic fibrosis but has not been shown to be effective for asthma.

C) INCORRECT:

Daily prednisone therapy should be avoided given its association with long-term adverse effects.

D) CORRECT:

Omalizumab, a recombinant immunoglobulin G subclass 1 monoclonal anti-immunoglobulin E (IgE) antibody that binds to IgE molecules at the fragment crystallizable region, reduces asthmatic responses to allergen inhalation challenges. Randomized clinical trials have shown that omalizumab can also be effective in patients with elevated total serum IgE levels and positive skin testing to aeroallergens (e.g., dust mites, cockroaches, or pet dander) by lowering the frequency and likelihood of asthma exacerbations. The drug has also been shown to reduce the dose of inhaled glucocorticoid necessary to control symptoms.

Key learning point: An anti-immunoglobulin E antibody that has been shown to be effective for reducing the frequency of exacerbations in patients with uncontrolled asthma is omalizumab.

E) INCORRECT:

Inhaled levalbuterol can be used as a bronchodilator instead of albuterol but has not been shown to be more effective than albuterol.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman reports new-onset shortness of breath, chest tightness, and wheezing. She has no fever or productive cough but does report increased pruritus in both hands. She works as a truck mechanic and auto body-repair technician with several coworkers who smoke cigarettes, but she does not smoke.
On physical examination, she is short of breath and tachypneic. Her temperature is 36.8°C, blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg, heart rate is 92 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 96% while she is breathing ambient air. Chest auscultation reveals bilateral diffuse wheezing. Cardiac examination is normal. Skin examination reveals mild excoriations on both hands but no other skin lesions.
The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
A chest radiograph is normal.
Which one of the following triggers is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Poisoning with heavy metals, such as lead, can occur in occupational settings, but they are much less likely than chemical irritants to cause respiratory symptoms. Metal fume inhalation has been associated with increased shortness of breath and pulmonary inflammation but is not a common cause of work-related asthma.

B) CORRECT:

Pruritus and asthma in an auto body-repair technician is consistent with occupation-related asthma, most likely related to exposure to diisocyanates, a type of chemical irritant.

Diisocyanate exposure, one of the most well-described causes of occupational asthma, should be suspected in people who use spray paint, make or repair automobiles, install insulation, or make plastic, rubber, or polyurethane foam. Other chemicals associated with occupation-related asthma include persulfates, aldehydes, and amines.

Key learning point: A common cause of work-related asthma among people who use spray paint or work in the auto body industry is exposure to chemical irritants, such as diisocyanates.

C) INCORRECT:

Diesel exhaust, bleaching agents, and secondhand cigarette smoke are less likely than diisocyanates to lead to both skin excoriation and respiratory symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Diesel exhaust, bleaching agents, and secondhand cigarette smoke are less likely than diisocyanates to lead to both skin excoriation and respiratory symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Diesel exhaust, bleaching agents, and secondhand cigarette smoke are less likely than diisocyanates to lead to both skin excoriation and respiratory symptoms.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man reports persistent cough, chest tightness, and wheezing since he started a new position as a stablehand 6 weeks ago. His symptoms are worse during the day than at night. He has no rhinitis, postnasal drip, or history of seasonal allergies. He takes no prescription or over-the-counter medications.
On physical examination, he is mildly uncomfortable but speaks in complete, uninterrupted sentences. His temperature is 37.0°C, blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, heart rate is 88 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 96% while he is breathing ambient air. Examination of his head and neck reveal normal nasal and oral mucosa, and no sinus tenderness. Chest auscultation reveals bilateral diffuse wheezing. Cardiac examination and chest radiograph are normal.
The patient’s leukocyte count is 7500 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000) with 70% neutrophils (40–70), 18% lymphocytes (22–44), 7% eosinophils (0–8), and 5% monocytes (4–11).
After the patient recovers from this acute episode, which one of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

After pulmonary function testing, dermal patch testing could be considered as a second step, as it may identify some irritants that trigger allergies.

B) INCORRECT:

If spirometry is normal, a bronchial challenge with methacholine should be performed to evaluate for asthma.

C) INCORRECT:

Aspergillus antibody testing to evaluate for allergic pulmonary aspergillosis and serum immunoglobulin E testing could be considered if the patient’s symptoms persist despite adequate medical management for 3 to 4 months.

D) INCORRECT:

Aspergillus antibody testing to evaluate for allergic pulmonary aspergillosis and serum immunoglobulin E testing could be considered if the patient’s symptoms persist despite adequate medical management for 3 to 4 months.

E) CORRECT:

Spirometry with pre- and postbronchodilator testing is the standard diagnostic approach for suspected asthma, as it assesses reversible airflow limitation. The clinician should also elicit a detailed social history to identify potential triggers of work-related asthma or allergies.

Key learning point: The most appropriate diagnostic test for a patient with new adult-onset asthma symptoms is spirometry with pre- and postbronchodilator testing.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old man presents with a cough that began about 6 months ago, when he had a cold, and has persisted despite resolution of the other cold symptoms. The cough is worse with exercise and exposure to cold air, and it occasionally occurs at night, but the patient does not recall it awakening him from sleep recently.
His vital signs are unremarkable. On examination, he coughs when asked to take deep breaths, and a faint expiratory wheeze is present. His nasal mucosa and the rest of the physical examination are normal. Spirometry findings are normal.
Which one of the following treatments is most likely to be successful in treating this patient's cough?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Long-acting beta-agonists should only be used in conjunction with an inhaled glucocorticoid when treating asthma, because monotherapy with long-acting beta-agonists has been associated with a higher rate of respiratory failure and death in patients with asthma.

B) CORRECT:

Viral respiratory tract infections can lead to the development of asthma in adults who were previously asymptomatic, although the mechanism by which this happens is unknown. This patient’s persistent cough, a likely manifestation of airway hyperresponsiveness, started after a common cold. Normal results on spirometry testing do not rule out asthma, because patients can have significant symptoms and still maintain normal lung function.

According to the current Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA) guidelines, the preferred initial treatment is an as-needed low-dose glucocorticoid-formoterol inhaler. A 2020 update from the National Asthma Education and Prevention Program (NAEPP) recommends beginning with a short-acting beta-agonist (SABA) if symptoms are intermittent; thus, as-needed albuterol would have been another acceptable option in this case. If an as-needed SABA alone is inadequate, then the NAEPP guidelines recommend stepping up to either an as-needed low-dose glucocorticoid-formoterol inhaler or a daily low-dose inhaled glucocorticoid.

See “Stepwise asthma treatment” table.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of a chronic cough that is exacerbated by cold air and exercise is asthma.

C) INCORRECT:

Although a leukotriene-receptor antagonist is also an alternative, it is not first-line therapy for asthma, and as-needed medications are preferred as a first step.

D) INCORRECT:

Guaifenesin, which would treat the symptom of cough but not the underlying cause, is not recommended.

E) INCORRECT:

Postnasal drip is a common cause of chronic cough, and a nasal glucocorticoid would be a good choice to treat allergic rhinitis; however, the presence of exercise- and cold-induced cough with the wheeze on examination makes asthma a more likely etiology for this patient’s cough.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old man is evaluated for a nighttime cough that has lasted 6 weeks. The patient says that he had asthma during childhood but that he has had no symptoms for 20 years. He has never smoked. He had an upper respiratory infection 6 to 8 weeks ago, from which he recovered. Now, his cough wakes him from sleep about 3 times per week; in addition, he has chest tightness with exercise that is relieved with rest.
His physical examination is normal, and auscultation of his chest reveals normal breath sounds. Spirometry demonstrates an FEV1 of 78% of predicted and an FEV1 /FVC ratio of 64%.
Which one of the following tests is most appropriate to determine whether this patient has asthma?

choices.text: Measurement of the peak expiratory flow rate
Measurement of FEV1 before and after the administration of an inhaled beta-agonist

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Measurement of the peak expiratory flow rate is not diagnostic, as asthma is only one possible cause of a reduced peak expiratory flow rate.

B) INCORRECT:

Airway hyperresponsiveness to a methacholine challenge test can be found in asthma, but it can also be seen in other non-asthma-related diseases. A methacholine challenge test could be considered in people with normal baseline spirometry or those who do not demonstrate variability in peak flow with serial spirometry. Because methacholine testing is more time-consuming and expensive than pre- and post-bronchodilator testing, it is reserved for patients who do not show variability in spirometry with inhaled beta-agonists.

C) INCORRECT:

Although some patients with asthma have an elevated serum immunoglobulin E level, measurement of serum immunoglobulin E is neither specific nor diagnostic of asthma.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with asthma usually have a normal chest radiograph.

E) CORRECT:

The clinical presentation of asthma is variable and often nonspecific, with symptoms including cough, dyspnea, and chest tightness. Asthma symptoms frequently occur at night and with exercise. Several clues suggest that this patient could have asthma: He had asthma as a child, his symptoms started after a respiratory infection, and his spirometry shows a reduced FEV1 /FVC ratio (diagnostic of obstruction) and a reduced FEV1 .

The best diagnostic test for asthma is to measure the FEV1 before and after the administration of an inhaled beta-agonist. Improvement in the FEV1 by at least 12% and 200 mL is diagnostic of a bronchodilator response that is the hallmark of asthma.

Key learning point: The best diagnostic test for asthma is measurement of FEV1 before and after the administration of an inhaled beta-agonist.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man with asthma reports wheezing or cough requiring use of his rescue inhaler 3 days per week. During the past year, he has used a low-dose inhaled glucocorticoid daily, but viral respiratory infections have caused two exacerbations of his asthma, necessitating short courses of an oral glucocorticoid. He has adhered to the inhaled therapy.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this patient's therapy?

choices.text: Add scheduled use of an inhaled short-acting beta-agonist

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Theophylline is rarely used in the management of asthma because it has a narrow therapeutic index requiring monitoring of serum concentrations, it interacts with other medications, and there are safer alternatives available that are at least as effective.

B) INCORRECT:

Adding a long-acting beta-agonist to a low-dose inhaled glucocorticoid is superior to adding cromolyn. Cromolyn is more commonly used in children; when used in adults, it is primarily reserved for treatment of exercise-induced asthma.

C) INCORRECT:

Adding a long-acting antimuscarinic agent would be reasonable; however, ipratropium is a short-acting antimuscarinic agent. It may help with control, but it would not be a preferred next step, and its frequent dosing makes adherence difficult.

D) INCORRECT:

Short-acting beta-agonists (SABAs) should not be used on a scheduled basis but instead should be reserved as a rescue medication to get quick relief from acute symptoms. Regular use of SABAs can lead to tachyphylaxis and inadequate rescue response.

E) CORRECT:

Asthma is not well controlled if the patient experiences symptoms more than 2 days per week while taking a low-dose glucocorticoid. In the stepwise approach to asthma management recommended by the Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA) and the National Asthma Education and Prevention Program (NAEPP), the next step would be to add a long-acting beta-agonist (LABA). The most recent guidelines recommend choosing formoterol as the LABA because it has rapid onset and thus can be used both as maintenance therapy and as a rescue medication. Acceptable alternatives would be to add a long-acting antimuscarinic (LAMA) or a leukotriene modifier to the low-dose glucocorticoid inhaler. Asthma control should be assessed again after 2 to 6 weeks of therapy, depending on the severity of symptoms.

See “Stepwise asthma treatment” table.

Key learning point: In an adult whose asthma is inadequately controlled with a low-dose inhaled glucocorticoid alone, the preferred next step in therapy is combination therapy with a low-dose inhaled glucocorticoid and a long-acting beta-agonist.

questions.text: Which one of the following tests can determine whether a patient with severe asthma will benefit from treatment with omalizumab?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sputum eosinophilia is a biomarker of specific asthma phenotypes but has no bearing on the decision of whether to use omalizumab.

B) INCORRECT:

Sputum neutrophilia is a biomarker of specific asthma phenotypes but has no bearing on the decision of whether to use omalizumab.

C) CORRECT:

Omalizumab is a monoclonal antibody directed against immunoglobulin E. It is indicated for patients who have persistent, moderate-to-severe asthma and evidence of respiratory allergies. The latter can be confirmed by immediate skin testing or by serum immunoglobulin E testing that is specific for perennial aeroallergens.

Key learning point: Omalizumab is indicated for patients with persistent, moderate-to-severe asthma who also have a positive test result for allergen-specific immunoglobulin E.

D) INCORRECT:

Even if allergen-specific immunoglobulin G antibodies were present, they would not be affected by omalizumab therapy. Moreover, there is no evidence to suggest that allergen-specific immunoglobulin G antibodies play any role in asthma pathogenesis.

E) INCORRECT:

Peripheral blood eosinophilia is a biomarker of specific asthma phenotypes but has no bearing on the decision of whether to use omalizumab.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man with a history of patellofemoral syndrome and seasonal allergies presents to establish care. He reports having intermittent shortness of breath with wheezing and cough. The symptoms have worsened in winter and now occur three or four days per week.
He was previously an avid jogger and participated in 5-km races but has been unable to do so for the past several months because of his dyspnea. He has an occasional nonproductive cough. He reports no orthopnea or lower-extremity swelling and has not been awakened from sleep with symptoms. He has never smoked.
On examination, he is afebrile, with a respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute, a heart rate of 73 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 126/65 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 98% while he breathes ambient air. He has mild erythema of his nasal turbinates with a clear discharge. His lungs are clear to auscultation, and cardiac examination is normal.
Spirometry reveals an FEV1 /FVC ratio of 0.82. The flow-volume loop is shown below (figure).
Which one of the following treatments is the most appropriate first-line therapy for this patient?

choices.text: Daily salmeterol inhaler with as-needed albuterol inhaler
Daily intranasal fluticasone and daily cetirizine

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has a clinical history consistent with asthma and a normal flow-volume loop on spirometry.

Diagnosing Asthma

Asthma is diagnosed based on clinical criteria together with historical and physical evidence of airway hyper-responsiveness and reversible airflow obstruction. Spirometry, a key diagnostic test for evaluating airflow obstruction and reversibility, should be the first step in evaluating for asthma. However, normal spirometry findings do not exclude a diagnosis of asthma because the airway obstruction seen in asthma can be episodic and variable, as described in this case. Thresholds for obstruction can be defined by specific demographic parameters determining a lower limit of normal (LLN) or by simple age-based cutoffs.

In this case, where no specific LLN is provided and the patient is a young adult (age 20–39), an FEV1 /FVC ratio of <0.70 would define obstruction. This patient’s FEV1 /FVC ratio (0.82) is therefore not diagnostic of obstruction. In addition, his flow-volume loop does not show the characteristic concave scooping of the expiratory limb that would be expected in obstruction. The inspiratory limb shows a normal rounding, and there is no clear sign of restriction, which would appear as a more narrowed flow-volume loop. The flow-volume loop shown here is thus not diagnostic.

In a patient whose clinical history is suggestive of poorly controlled asthma but whose spirometry is not diagnostic of asthma, treatment should still be initiated because the diagnosis can be made on the history provided. Although not indicated in this case, confirmatory testing can be considered in patients who do not respond to therapy or if there is a question of a confounding illness, such as another cardiac or pulmonary condition. Bronchoprovocation testing (with either exercise or methacholine) can be used to diagnose asthma in the setting of normal spirometry. An FEV1 decline of 15% with exercise or 20% with a methacholine challenge is considered diagnostic.

Treating Asthma

Two major guidelines are available to guide clinicians treating asthma — the Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA) guidelines, last updated in 2023, and the National Asthma Education and Prevention Program (NAEPP) guidelines, updated in 2020. Both guidelines use a stepwise approach in which the control of asthma symptoms guides the choice of appropriate treatment, but they differ somewhat on the details of which specific agent to use in each step. See “Stepwise asthma treatment” table.

In this case, the patient’s asthma symptoms are mild but persistent, thus warranting therapy. The preferred first step of therapy varies between the two guidelines. In the GINA guidelines, the preferred first step is an as-needed budesonide-formoterol inhaler. In contrast, the NAEPP guidelines recommend a daily low-dose glucocorticoid inhaler with an as-needed short-acting beta-agonist as a rescue medication.

Although as-needed use of a low-dose glucocorticoid-formoterol inhaler has been shown to be equivalent to a daily low-dose glucocorticoid inhaler with respect to frequency of severe exacerbations, the as-needed combination inhaler is associated with slightly worse control of symptoms. Thus, when symptom control is an issue, starting a daily low-dose glucocorticoid inhaler is reasonable. A leukotriene-receptor antagonist is considered an alternative to the low-dose inhaled glucocorticoid but is not first-line therapy.

Long-acting beta-agonists (LABAs) should not be used alone as maintenance therapy in patients with asthma, as some studies suggest an increase in exacerbations and mortality when these agents are used as monotherapy. The effects seem to diminish when LABAs are used in combination with inhaled glucocorticoids. Postmarketing clinical safety trials have shown that the long-term use of LABAs in fixed-dose combination with inhaled glucocorticoids does not increase the risk for asthma-related events, including hospitalization, intubation, or asthma-related death. As a result, in December 2017, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration removed a boxed warning regarding asthma-related deaths from combination inhalers containing an inhaled glucocorticoid and a LABA.

Key learning point: The most appropriate first-line therapy for a patient who has a clinical history suggestive of mild, persistent asthma symptoms but normal spirometry is either a daily low-dose glucocorticoid inhaler with an as-needed short-acting bronchodilator or a combination budesonide-formoterol inhaler as needed.

B) INCORRECT:

A scheduled long-acting beta-agonist (LABA) such as daily salmeterol is only indicated for more severe symptoms than seen in this case. Moreover, inhaled corticosteroid therapy should accompany treatment with a LABA.

C) INCORRECT:

A combination inhaler with a medium-dose inhaled glucocorticoid and a long-acting beta-agonist (e.g., salmeterol) is recommended for patients with more severe symptoms than seen in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

In patients with mild persistent asthma, a short-acting beta-agonist (e.g., albuterol) can be used as a rescue inhaler (i.e., on an as-needed basis) but it should not be used alone.

E) INCORRECT:

Treatment of concurrent allergic rhinitis with an intranasal glucocorticoid and an oral second-generation antihistamine may be necessary in patients with asthma, but maintenance therapy for asthma is a higher priority in a patient with persistent asthma.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old man with asthma presents to clinic in mild respiratory distress. He has a persistent, dry cough and is short of breath. His current medications include fluticasone 110 μg two puffs twice daily and albuterol as needed. He reports taking these medications as prescribed and, when asked, demonstrates proper technique using the inhaler with a spacer. For the past 6 months, he has been using his albuterol rescue inhaler 5 to 6 times per week and wakes at night with a cough at least once per week. During the past 24 hours, he has used the albuterol inhaler every 6 hours with minimal relief. He is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
On examination, he is afebrile and has a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute, a heart rate of 92 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 96/64 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 96% while he breathes ambient air. He is able to converse but is mildly dyspneic after each sentence. Auscultation reveals good aeration but diffuse expiratory wheezes and a prolonged inspiratory-to-expiratory ratio.
Albuterol treatment in the office improves his symptoms but yields no change in oxygen saturation. A dose of oral prednisone is given. This is the third time in the past year that he has required a short course of oral glucocorticoids.
In addition to a 5-day course of oral glucocorticoids, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for long-term control of this patient's asthma?

choices.text: Stop the fluticasone; switch to a fluticasone-salmeterol combination inhaler

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Two major guidelines are available to guide clinicians treating asthma — the 2023 Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA) guidelines and the 2020 National Asthma Education and Prevention Program (NAEPP) guidelines. Both guidelines use a stepwise approach in which the control of asthma symptoms guides the choice of appropriate treatment, but they differ somewhat on the details of which specific agent to use in each step (see “Stepwise asthma treatment” table).

In this case, the patient’s asthma is not well controlled with a medium-dose inhaled glucocorticoid. The preferred next step, according to both sets of guidelines, is to stop the fluticasone and start an inhaler that includes both a medium-dose glucocorticoid and a long-acting beta-agonist (LABA). Fluticasone-salmeterol is one option, but budesonide-formoterol would have the added benefit of being able to be used both daily (as maintenance therapy) and as needed (as a rescue medication).

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step in care for a patient whose asthma is not well controlled with a medium-dose inhaled glucocorticoid is to add an inhaled long-acting beta-agonist.

B) INCORRECT:

Stopping this patient’s fluticasone and starting theophylline is not recommended, as daily glucocorticoids are part of every step of preferred therapy for persistent asthma. Although theophylline can be added to a glucocorticoid inhaler in some scenarios, this is considered an alternative, rather than a preferred, approach.

C) INCORRECT:

Stopping this patient’s fluticasone and starting salmeterol or another LABA alone is not advisable. Use of a LABA as a stand-alone maintenance medication may increase the risk of asthma-related adverse events, including hospitalization and even death. In the treatment of asthma, LABAs should be used only in combination with a glucocorticoid.

D) INCORRECT:

A daily oral glucocorticoid, such as prednisone, would be too aggressive for this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Adding both montelukast (a leukotriene-receptor antagonist) and salmeterol to a glucocorticoid is not recommended at any stage of asthma management. Montelukast alone can be added to a glucocorticoid in some scenarios, but this is considered an alternative, rather than a preferred, approach.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl with a history of intermittent asthma presents for routine evaluation. She has had three wheezing episodes in the past year. The child’s father is concerned that the episodes may have been caused by the family’s new kitten, but he acknowledges that there are smokers in the home and mold in the basement.
Which one of the following initial steps is most appropriate in attempting to reduce this child’s incidence of wheezing episodes?

choices.text: Reduce the exposure to secondhand smoke
Find a new home for the kitten
Place plastic covers on the mattresses to reduce exposure to dust mites

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Asthma and other respiratory diseases in children can be triggered and exacerbated by many environmental risk factors, of which tobacco smoke is the most common. Reducing the level of all potential environmental triggers is important, but limiting exposure to secondhand smoke should be the first step for a child with such exposure. The primary indoor air pollutants associated with asthma exacerbations are environmental tobacco smoke, biologic allergens, and irritant chemicals and fumes.

Biologic allergens (e.g., dust mites, cockroaches, mold, and animal dander) can exacerbate asthma in patients with known asthma and may be linked to the development of asthma, but the secondhand smoke should be addressed first.

Key learning point: The most common environmental trigger for asthma exacerbations in children is secondhand tobacco smoke.

B) INCORRECT:

Removing mold may help reduce the incidence of wheezing episodes if mold is a specific trigger for the child, but it is not the most important first step.

C) INCORRECT:

Specific allergy testing may help to identify triggers for this child, but because tobacco smoke is a trigger for all children, addressing that risk factor is the best first step.

D) INCORRECT:

Cat dander can be an allergic trigger for wheezing in some children, but whether this child has an allergy to cats is unknown.

E) INCORRECT:

Plastic mattress covers help to reduce exposure to dust mites, which can be a trigger for some children, but the secondhand smoke should be addressed first.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old girl with asthma presents to the emergency department with an asthma flare. She developed cold symptoms a few days ago and has been using albuterol every 4 hours today without relief of her symptoms. She is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
She has a heart rate of 130 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 45 breaths per minute, a blood pressure of 120/80 mm Hg, a temperature of 37.5°C, and an oxygen saturation of 92% while breathing ambient air. She is in respiratory distress and is having trouble speaking more than a few words at a time. She has inspiratory and expiratory wheezing with suprasternal retractions.
After receiving oral prednisolone and nebulized albuterol, she no longer has any inspiratory or expiratory wheezing but continues to have nasal flaring and suprasternal and intercostal retractions and is breathless with even two-word phrases.
In addition to providing supplemental oxygen and continuous albuterol while establishing intravenous access, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Montelukast (a leukotriene-receptor antagonist) is used as a long-term controller medication but is not useful during acute exacerbations.

B) INCORRECT:

Theophylline (a methylxanthine) is used as long-term controller medication but is not useful during acute exacerbations.

C) INCORRECT:

Magnesium sulfate is indicated for patients who have severe asthma exacerbations or are deteriorating, but it must be administered intravenously. This patient does not have intravenous access and is acutely worsening. If the patient already had intravenous access, magnesium could also be administered, but if there is any delay in starting the magnesium, epinephrine should be used for more immediate relief. Magnesium sulfate may also cause hypotension, so it is important to make sure the patient is well hydrated before administration or to administer the magnesium sulfate with a normal saline bolus.

D) CORRECT:

This patient presented in status asthmaticus triggered by an upper respiratory infection with severe tachypnea, inspiratory and expiratory wheeze, and increased work of breathing. She received appropriate initial glucocorticoid and beta-agonist therapy, but the disappearance of her wheezing with increased work of breathing suggests that she is actually worsening. While awaiting intravenous access, she should be on continuous albuterol and receive a dose of intramuscular or subcutaneous epinephrine or terbutaline as parenteral beta-agonist therapy, to provide immediate bronchospasm relief.

Key learning point: In a patient with asthma who is acutely worsening despite treatment with glucocorticoids and inhaled beta-agonist therapy and who lacks intravenous access, the most appropriate next step is to administer intramuscular or subcutaneous epinephrine or terbutaline.

E) INCORRECT:

Intubation is indicated for patients in imminent risk of respiratory failure, after all other medical therapies have been exhausted.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy who was diagnosed with asthma at 3 years of age is seen for a well-child visit. His mother states that he uses his albuterol inhaler two to three times per week for symptoms and wakes about once per week with coughing and wheezing. In the past year, he has had one hospitalization for asthma and has had two other asthma exacerbations requiring oral glucocorticoids.
He is an active boy, but his mother notes that she has “to make him sit out” from physical activity at times because he seems out of breath.
His vital signs are within normal limits for his age. He appears comfortable, and his ear, nose, throat, and cardiac examinations are normal. His lungs are well aerated, with no prolonged expiratory phase and no wheezes.
Which one of the following next steps is best in managing this boy’s asthma?

choices.text: Instruct the family to administer albuterol before the boy exercises
Instruct the family to keep a diary of the boy's symptoms and use of albuterol, and return for further evaluation in 2 to 6 weeks
Initiate a 5-day course of prednisolone, to be followed by initiation of long-term inhaled fluticasone

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A short-acting beta-agonist should be prescribed for use before exercise, given the evidence of exercise-induced bronchospasm in this patient; however, this therapy alone would not be sufficient to control the patient's asthma and should be prescribed in conjunction with inhaled glucocorticoid therapy.

B) CORRECT:

This child’s mild persistent asthma is characterized by both impairment (nighttime awakenings, frequent symptoms requiring short-acting beta-agonist therapy, and mild exercise limitation) and risk (one hospitalization and multiple courses of systemic glucocorticoids in the past year). Initiation of a low-dose inhaled glucocorticoid, such as fluticasone, is therefore indicated. The inhaled medications should be delivered using a spacer device, and the clinician should provide the parents with an asthma action plan that summarizes the treatment plan.

Key learning point: The appropriate next step for a child with mild persistent asthma who is not currently using long-term daily control medication is initiation of inhaled glucocorticoid therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Instructing the family to keep a diary of symptoms and return in 2 to 6 weeks would be appropriate after initiation of inhaled glucocorticoid therapy. This patient's current clinical situation warrants initiation of therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Treating an active asthma exacerbation with a course of an oral glucocorticoid (prednisolone) would be reasonable however, this patient does not appear to have signs of an acute exacerbation.

E) INCORRECT:

Leukotriene inhibitors such as montelukast are not first-line therapy for persistent asthma, but they can be used as adjunctive or alternative therapy.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of shortness of breath, wheezing, and increased work of breathing that has progressed despite albuterol treatments every 4 hours.
This is the patient’s fourth visit to the emergency department within the past 6 months for similar symptoms, and she has had two courses of glucocorticoids within that time frame. Her father reports that she uses her albuterol inhaler four times per week for shortness of breath during activity and wakes up one to two times per week because of coughing fits. Her father also reports that she uses a medium-dose inhaled glucocorticoid with a spacer twice daily as prescribed. The patient has seasonal allergies but is otherwise healthy. Her father occasionally smokes, but other family members are healthy without any underlying conditions.
She is afebrile, her heart rate is 145 beats per minute, her respiratory rate is 42 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 94% while she is breathing ambient air. She has difficulty completing full sentences and is in moderate respiratory distress with tachypnea, intercostal retractions, reduced aeration in both lungs, diffuse expiratory wheezing, and a prolonged expiratory phase.
In addition to managing this patient’s acute asthma exacerbation and providing education on environmental triggers, what is the most appropriate recommendation for outpatient management?

choices.text: Increase the dose of the inhaled glucocorticoid

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inhaled glucocorticoids should be used at the lowest dose possible that still maintains asthma control. Increasing the dose of this patient’s inhaled glucocorticoid would increase the risk for adverse glucocorticoid-related effects, such as posterior subcapsular cataracts, reduced bone mineral density, and reduced linear growth. High-dose inhaled glucocorticoids are not indicated until the medium dose has been tried in combination with either an LABA or an LTRA.

B) INCORRECT:

Cromolyn sodium is a mast-cell stabilizer indicated as preventive treatment for exercise-induced asthma and for patients with mild persistent asthma who use a low-dose inhaled glucocorticoid. This adjunctive agent are not as effective as LABAs or LTRAs in treating moderate-to-severe persistent asthma.

C) CORRECT:

The goal of asthma therapy is to minimize symptoms and exacerbations while providing only the amount of medications necessary with the fewest adverse effects. A patient's asthma is considered to be well controlled if there are symptoms ≤2 days per week, nighttime awakenings less than once per month, use of a short-acting beta-agonist for symptom control ≤2 days per week, ≤1 exacerbation requiring oral systemic glucocorticoids per year, and no interference with daily activities.

This child has had several recent hospitalizations and has symptoms consistent with poorly controlled asthma. Given that her father reports adherence to the current therapy and use of a spacer device, the child’s medication needs to be escalated. Identification of contributing conditions and avoidance of triggers are critical components of successful asthma management.

Escalating Treatment in This Case

Given the failure of the current medium-dose inhaled glucocorticoid for this patient, and the existence of potential triggers (secondhand smoke) and contributing conditions (allergic rhinitis), the next step would be to institute step-4 therapy as recommended by the 2007 NIH Asthma Guidelines. A leukotriene-receptor antagonist (LTRA), such as montelukast, or a long-acting beta-agonist (LABA), such as salmeterol, should therefore be added to her therapy.

• The addition of a LABA improves lung function, decreases symptoms, and reduces exacerbations and the need for use of short-acting beta-agonists.
• LTRAs are especially useful in patients with allergic rhinitis because these agents interfere with the pathway of leukotriene mediators, which are released from mast cells, eosinophils, and basophils.

Caution Regarding Montelukast

Although montelukast is helpful for many children, it carries a boxed warning regarding the potential for neuropsychiatric symptoms, including suicidal thoughts and behavior. The most commonly reported neuropsychiatric symptoms with montelukast are depression, aggression, headaches, and nightmares or vivid dreams.

A study conducted in 2015 found that of the 14,670 safety reports on montelukast, 2630 (18%) were psychiatric. The most commonly reported psychiatric adverse effects varied by age group: sleep disorders in patients <2 years of age; depression and anxiety in those aged 2 to 11 years; and depression, anxiety, and suicidal behavior in those aged 12 to 17 years.

The FDA recommends that clinicians take the following precautions when considering or prescribing montelukast:

• Ask patients about any history of psychiatric illness before initiating montelukast.
• Consider the risks and benefits of montelukast when deciding to prescribe or continue patients on this medication.
• Advise all patients of the risk of neuropsychiatric events when prescribing montelukast.
• Monitor for neuropsychiatric symptoms in all patients treated with montelukast, even in the absence of psychiatric disease.
• Advise patients (and parents/caregivers) that they should stop taking montelukast and contact a health care professional immediately if any changes in behavior or new neuropsychiatric symptoms are noted or if suicidal thoughts or behaviors occur.

Neuropsychiatric symptoms associated with montelukast typically resolve after the medication is stopped. If this patient were to develop any neuropsychiatric symptoms, the medication should be stopped, and a LABA should be added for asthma control.

Key learning point: In a 9-year-old girl with poorly controlled asthma, seasonal allergies, and environmental triggers who is currently using a medium-dose inhaled glucocorticoid, the appropriate stepwise management in her pharmacologic therapy is to add a long-acting beta-agonist or leukotriene-receptor antagonist to her current therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin is used to treat bacterial pneumonia, but this patient does not have symptoms consistent with that diagnosis, such as focal rales, fever, or a productive cough.

E) INCORRECT:

Nedocromil is a mast-cell stabilizer indicated as preventive treatment for exercise-induced asthma and for patients with mild persistent asthma who use a low-dose inhaled glucocorticoid. This adjunctive agent is not as effective as LABAs or LTRAs in treating moderate-to-severe persistent asthma.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl with a history of asthma presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of rhinorrhea and cough that has progressed, during the past day, to wheezing and increased work of breathing. Use of albuterol every 6 hours for the past 24 hours has yielded no improvement.
The patient has been eating and drinking normally without vomiting. Her urine output has been adequate. She has no other medical problems. Her only medications are a daily, inhaled glucocorticoid and a short-acting beta-agonist, each administered using a metered-dose inhaler with spacer. She has no allergies. Testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
Her temperature is 37.5°C, her heart rate is 130 beats per minute, her respiratory rate is 50 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 92% while she breathes ambient air. She is alert and speaking in one-word utterances. Aeration is diminished in both lungs, with diffuse expiratory wheezes and prolonged expiration. She has intercostal retractions. She is tachycardic with a regular rhythm. Her capillary refill is less than 2 seconds. The rest of her examination is within normal limits.
The patient is given an albuterol-ipratropium nebulizer and a systemic glucocorticoid. An hour after the treatment, her heart rate is 150 beats per minute, her respiratory rate is 40 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 95% while she breathes ambient air. She is more talkative and aeration has improved, but the bilateral expiratory wheezes and intercostal retractions persist.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Initiate bilevel positive airway pressure support ventilation by facemask
Administer a bolus of intravenous magnesium
Continue albuterol and ipratropium nebulizer treatments every 4 hours
Administer two more albuterol-ipratropium nebulizer treatments

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient's condition is improving, so despite the persistent retractions and wheeze, respiratory support with bilevel positive airway pressure is not necessary.

B) INCORRECT:

A chest radiograph is not recommended for routine assessment but should be obtained if there is concern about a complicating process, such as a pneumothorax or confirmation of pneumonia, or to rule out an alternative diagnosis such as congestive heart failure.

C) INCORRECT:

If this patient has severe symptoms after maximizing therapy with oxygen, albuterol, and ipratropium, then intravenous magnesium should be considered.

D) INCORRECT:

She requires additional albuterol and ipratropium treatments; many protocols call for three back-to-back or “stacked” treatments at the time of presentation or a short course of continuous nebulized albuterol. Studies have shown a reduction in hospital admissions for patients who receive ipratropium in addition to a short acting beta-agonist while in the emergency department. No benefit of continued inpatient treatment with ipratropium has been shown.

E) CORRECT:

Fewer than 25% of patients who present to the emergency department with an asthma flare require hospitalization. Nebulized albuterol and ipratropium improved this patient’s breathlessness, respiratory rate, oxygen saturation, and aeration, but her wheeze and respiratory distress persist. She requires additional albuterol and ipratropium treatments; many protocols call for three back-to-back or “stacked” treatments at the time of presentation or a short course of continuous nebulized albuterol. If this patient has severe symptoms after maximizing therapy with oxygen, albuterol, and ipratropium, then intravenous magnesium should be considered.

Studies have shown a reduction in hospital admissions for patients who receive ipratropium in addition to a short acting beta-agonist while in the emergency department. No benefit of continued inpatient treatment with ipratropium has been shown.

Key learning point: When a child presenting to the emergency department with a severe asthma exacerbation receives an albuterol-ipratropium nebulizer with an oral glucocorticoid and her examination findings improve while her symptoms persist, the most appropriate next step is to administer additional albuterol-ipratropium treatments every 2 hours and continue the oral glucocorticoid.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old woman in her second trimester of pregnancy reports increased wheezing and shortness of breath. She has a history of intermittent asthma that was well controlled with as-needed albuterol until a month ago when she needed to start using her albuterol inhaler once a day on most days of the week. The current dose usually relieves her symptoms, but she did wake with wheezing one night during the past week.
She has had no change in environmental exposures and no recent illness. She does not smoke, and her last pulmonary function tests were in her early twenties.
Physical examination reveals normal vital signs, including an oxygen saturation of 98% while she is breathing ambient air. Her peak flow is 78% of predicted, and her lung examination is notable for diffuse wheezes throughout.
What is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Prescribe scheduled albuterol four times daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fewer studies have been conducted on the safety of leukotriene modifiers than on other asthma medications during pregnancy. The limited data focused on the use of montelukast are reassuring; however, adverse events have been noted in animal studies of zileuton. For this reason, zileuton is generally avoided in pregnancy.

B) CORRECT:

This patient requires a step-up in her asthma therapy. Taking asthma medications is safer for pregnant women than having asthma symptoms and exacerbations, which place the fetus at risk for hypoxemia.

According to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, the first-line treatment for pregnant women with mild asthma is a low-dose inhaled glucocorticoid. Budesonide has been shown to be safe among pregnant women and has emerged as the preferred glucocorticoid for this population.

Key learning point: The most appropriate first-line treatment for a pregnant woman with mild asthma is a low-dose inhaled glucocorticoid.

C) INCORRECT:

If a low-dose inhaled glucocorticoid does not prove effective for this patient, use of a medium-dose glucocorticoid (such as beclomethasone) may be considered.

D) INCORRECT:

Guidelines from the Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA) support the first-line use of a low-dose glucocorticoid-formoterol inhaler for mild asthma, although this approach has not been specifically tested in pregnant women. The use of inhaled formoterol alone is not recommended in the management of asthma.

E) INCORRECT:

According to the latest GINA guidelines, albuterol and other short-acting bronchodilators are no longer recommended for as-needed therapy, because they increase the risk of asthma exacerbations, and overuse can reduce responsiveness. More important, this patient needs better control of her asthma, and step-up therapy is warranted.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy with asthma presents to clinic in mild respiratory distress. He has a persistent, dry cough and is short of breath. He is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
His current medications include fluticasone 110 μg two puffs twice daily and albuterol as needed. He reports taking these medications as prescribed and, when asked, demonstrates proper technique using the inhaler with a spacer. For the past 6 months, he has been using his albuterol rescue inhaler 5 to 6 times per week and wakes at night with a cough at least once per week. During the past 24 hours, he has used the albuterol inhaler every 6 hours with minimal relief.
On examination, he is afebrile and has a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute, a heart rate of 92 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 96/64 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 96% while he breathes ambient air. He is able to converse but is mildly dyspneic after each sentence. Auscultation reveals good aeration but diffuse expiratory wheezes and a prolonged inspiratory-to-expiratory ratio.
Albuterol treatment in the office improves his symptoms but yields no change in oxygen saturation. A dose of oral prednisone is given. This is the third time in the past year that he has required a short course of oral glucocorticoids.
In addition to a 5-day course of oral glucocorticoids, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for long-term control of this patient's asthma?

choices.text: Stop the fluticasone; start a budesonide-formoterol combination inhaler

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adding both montelukast (a leukotriene receptor antagonist) and formoterol to a glucocorticoid is not recommended at any stage of asthma management for any age of patient. Montelukast alone can be added to a glucocorticoid in some scenarios, but this is considered an alternative, rather than a preferred, approach.

B) INCORRECT:

Stopping this patient’s fluticasone and starting formoterol or another LABA alone is not advisable. Use of a LABA as a stand-alone controller medication may increase the risk of asthma-related adverse events, including hospitalization and even death. In the treatment of asthma, LABAs should be used only in combination with a glucocorticoid.

C) CORRECT:

This patient is currently using a medium-dose inhaled glucocorticoid daily without adequate control of his symptoms and should have his therapy advanced with the addition of a long-acting beta-agonist (LABA). Use of a combination inhaler is the best way to ensure adherence to this regimen. Budesonide-formoterol is one such option and should be used both daily (as a controller medication) and as needed (for rescue, instead of albuterol). Often, an asthma specialist would be consulted at this point.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step in care for an adolescent whose asthma is not well-controlled with a medium-dose inhaled glucocorticoid is to add a long-acting inhaled beta-adrenergic agonist.

D) INCORRECT:

Stopping this patient’s fluticasone and starting theophylline is also not recommended as daily glucocorticoids are part of every step of preferred therapy for persistent asthma. Although theophylline can be added to a glucocorticoid inhaler in some scenarios, this is considered an alternative, rather than a preferred, approach.

E) INCORRECT:

A daily oral glucocorticoid, such as prednisone, would be too aggressive for this patient.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presents with a cough that began about 6 months ago. The cough started when the patient had a cold, but it persisted after his cold symptoms resolved. The cough is worse with exercise and exposure to cold air, and it is particularly troublesome at night. In fact, the patient awakens with the cough about once per week.
The patient's vital signs are unremarkable. On examination, he coughs when asked to take deep breaths, and a faint expiratory wheeze is present. His nasal mucosa and the rest of the physical examination are normal. Spirometry findings are normal.
Which one of the following treatments, in conjunction with a short-acting beta-agonist, is most likely to be successful in treating the patient's cough?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Viral respiratory tract infections can lead to the development of asthma in patients who were previously asymptomatic, although the mechanism by which this happens is unknown. This patient’s chronic asthmatic cough, a likely manifestation of airway hyperresponsiveness, started after a common cold. Normal results on spirometry testing do not rule out asthma, because patients can have significant symptoms and still maintain normal lung function. The preferred treatment for mild persistent asthma is an inhaled glucocorticoid.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of a chronic cough that is exacerbated by cold air and exercise and that worsens during sleep is asthma.

B) INCORRECT:

Guaifenesin, which would treat the symptom of cough but not the underlying cause, is not recommended.

C) INCORRECT:

Although a leukotriene-receptor antagonist may be helpful, it is not first-line therapy for asthma.

D) INCORRECT:

Postnasal drip is a common cause of chronic cough, and a nasal glucocorticoid would be a good choice to treat allergic rhinitis; however, the presence of exercise- and cold-induced cough with the wheeze on examination makes asthma a more likely etiology for this patient’s cough.

E) INCORRECT:

Long-acting beta-agonists should only be used in conjunction with an inhaled glucocorticoid when treating asthma.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her foster parents, who report that she has been experiencing congestion, cough, rhinorrhea, and increased work of breathing for the past 3 days. They report that she has been refusing solid foods for at least 12 hours.
The only birth history the parents have is that the patient was born “slightly early.” They note that she has a history of dry skin and that she once received albuterol and a “steroid liquid” for wheezing, but they do not currently have albuterol at home. She has not had any fevers, vomiting, or diarrhea. She is fully immunized, takes no medications, and has no known allergies. Testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
On examination, she is irritable, difficult to console, and cries when approached. She has a temperature of 37.7°C, a heart rate of 160 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 52 breaths per minute, and a blood pressure of 85/45 mm Hg. Her oxygen saturation is 94% while she is breathing ambient air and improves to 96% with 2 liters of oxygen via nasal cannula. There is audible nasal congestion with yellow-green rhinorrhea. No murmur is heard on cardiac examination. She has diffuse expiratory wheezing and a slightly prolonged expiratory phase.
She is given three albuterol-ipratropium nebulizer treatments and oral glucocorticoids over the course of one hour, resulting in sustained improvement in wheezing but continued moderate subcostal and intercostal chest-wall retractions. Auscultation continues to reveal diffuse coarse crackles. After her last treatment, the patient is noted to be less agitated and is now napping with an oxygen saturation of 93% while receiving supplemental oxygen by nasal cannula. Repeat vital signs show a heart rate of 180 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute, and a blood pressure of 88/47 mm Hg. The patient is sleepy but is arousable to moderate rubbing of the chest.
Testing of venous blood gas and electrolyte levels yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


pH
7.29
7.35–7.45


Partial pressure of carbon dioxide (mm Hg)
68
32–48


Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
31
20–28


Sodium (mEq/liter)
134
135–147


Potassium (mEq/liter)
3.0
3.4–4.7


Glucose (mg/dL)
110
60–100


What is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Administer an intravenous bolus of magnesium sulfate
Space the albuterol nebulizer treatments to 2 hours

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Repeating blood gas testing would not be appropriate for this patient, as it would delay urgent intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient’s diffuse crackles are most likely a consequence of her reactive airway disease. Without focal findings, fever, or significant hypoxemia, pneumonia is a less likely diagnosis. Administration of intravenous antibiotics is therefore not the most appropriate next step for this patient, and further testing (such as chest radiography) should be postponed until the patient’s worsening respiratory status is properly addressed.

C) CORRECT:

This patient presents with symptoms of a severe asthma exacerbation. Appropriate initial management of such an exacerbation consists of stacked inhaled albuterol and systemic glucocorticoids. Despite appropriate initial treatment and tachypnea, this patient is retaining carbon dioxide, as indicated by her elevated partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2). She also has altered mental status (becoming less agitated and more somnolent), an ominous sign in cases of respiratory distress.

Children who present with increasing irritability, inconsolability, lethargy, or changes in feeding may be exhibiting the initial signs of respiratory failure. They may present with tachypnea, bradypnea, or a falsely normal respiratory rate during this period. Venous blood gas testing will identify a progressive respiratory acidosis, with a PaCO2 >45 mm Hg and a pH <7.30, depending on the duration of illness.

The most appropriate next step for this patient is an intravenous bolus of magnesium sulfate (typically 50 mg/kg, with a range of 25–75 mg/kg and a maximum dose of 2 grams). Magnesium is recommended for children with severe asthma and as the next-line agent for those with moderate asthma who have not responded to initial therapy. Magnesium sulfate is safe, inexpensive, and widely available with minimal adverse effects. Intravenous magnesium sulfate causes relaxation of bronchial smooth muscle and, when administered with bronchodilators and glucocorticoids, has been shown to reduce hospitalizations in children with asthma exacerbations. Coadministration of intravenous saline may help to prevent hypotension, a rare adverse effect of magnesium.

Noninvasive ventilatory support (e.g., bilevel positive airway pressure) may also be initiated in addition to the continuous administration of albuterol and magnesium sulfate.

Key learning point: When a patient with an asthma exacerbation remains tachypneic, with limited response to stacked albuterol treatments and glucocorticoids, and is found to have an acute respiratory acidosis, the most appropriate next pharmacologic step is to administer magnesium sulfate.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient’s diffuse crackles are most likely a consequence of her reactive airway disease. Without focal findings, fever, or significant hypoxemia, pneumonia is a less likely diagnosis. Administration of intravenous antibiotics is therefore not the most appropriate next step for this patient, and further testing (such as chest radiography) should be postponed until the patient’s worsening respiratory status is properly addressed.

E) INCORRECT:

Although this patient’s wheezing is improving, her physical examination and venous blood gas testing indicate that she is retaining carbon dioxide. She should therefore receive continuous albuterol at this time, not spaced doses.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy with a history of seasonal allergies and eczema presents to establish care. He reports having intermittent shortness of breath with wheezing and cough. The symptoms occur a few days a week but not daily and have worsened in the winter months.
He was previously an avid runner and participated in 5-km races but has been unable to do so for the past several months because of his dyspnea. He has an occasional nonproductive cough. Three to four times during the past month, he has awoken from sleep with a sensation of chest tightness and shortness of breath. He denies syncope, night sweats, or weight loss. He has never smoked.
On examination, he is afebrile, with a respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute, a heart rate of 73 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 105/70 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 98% while he breathes ambient air. He has mild erythema of his nasal turbinates with a clear discharge. His lungs are clear to auscultation, and cardiac examination is normal.
Spirometry reveals an FEV1 /FVC ratio of 0.82. The flow-volume loop is shown below (figure).
Which one of the following treatments is the most appropriate first-line therapy for this patient?

choices.text: Low-dose inhaled glucocorticoid with a short-acting beta-agonist inhaler as needed
Combination inhaler with an inhaled glucocorticoid and a long-acting beta-agonist
Intranasal glucocorticoid and oral second-generation antihistamine
Long-acting beta-agonist with a short-acting beta-agonist inhaler as needed

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A short-acting beta-agonist alone is not sufficient to treat persistent asthma.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has a clinical history consistent with asthma and a normal flow-volume loop on spirometry.

Diagnosing Asthma

Asthma is diagnosed based on clinical criteria together with historical and physical evidence of airway hyper-responsiveness and reversible airflow obstruction. Spirometry, a key diagnostic test for evaluating airflow obstruction and reversibility, should be the first step in evaluating for asthma in children older than 6 years of age. However, normal spirometry findings do not exclude a diagnosis of asthma because the airway obstruction seen in asthma can be episodic and variable, as described in this case. Furthermore, there is a wide range of normal values, so although this patient’s results are in the normal range, his baseline may be much higher.

Thresholds for obstruction can be defined by specific demographic parameters determining a lower limit of normal (LLN) or by simple age-based cutoffs.
